title: Charleston Trident Home Builders v. Town Council of Town of Summerville
description: This case involves a challenge to a development impact fee ordinance on several statutory grounds.
text:
Charleston Trident v. Summerville


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Charleston Trident Home Builders, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Town Council of Town of Summerville and Town of Summerville,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
Patrick R. Watts, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 26181
Heard March 21, 2006 - Filed July 10, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Stephen P. Groves, Sr., R. Bruce Wallace, and Jeffrey S. Tibbals, of Nexsen Pruet, LLC, of Charleston, for appellant.
William H. Davidson, II, and Kenneth P. Woodington, of Davidson, Morrison & Lindemann, P.A., of Columbia for respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant Charleston Trident Home Builders, Inc. (Trident) is a non-profit corporation whose members construct homes, and own and develop property within the town limits of respondent Town of Summerville (Town).Â  Trident commenced this action challenging Townâ€™s development impact fee ordinance which was enacted in 2003 pursuant to the South Carolina Development Impact Fee Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-1-910 et seq. (2004) (the Act).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Act defines a development impact fee as â€œa payment of money imposed as a condition of development approval to pay a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements needed to serve the people utilizing the improvements.â€Â  Â§ 6-1-920(8). Â The Act requires that the local planning commission conduct studies and make recommendations for a capital improvements plan and impact fees by service unit.[1]Â  Â§ 6-1-950.Â  After notice and a public hearing, the capital improvements plan may then be adopted by the local government.Â  Â§ 9-1-960(A).Â  A capital improvements plan is required before an impact fee ordinance can be enacted.Â  Â§ 6-1-930.Â  The revenue from impact fees must be maintained in a separate account and used only for â€œthe category of system improvements and within or for the benefit of the service area for which the impact fee was imposed as shown by the capital improvements plan.â€ Â§ 6-1-1010.
To comply with the Act, in February 2001 Town Council directed Townâ€™s planning commission to conduct studies for an impact fee.Â  Town hired Tischler & Associates, Inc., a consulting firm, to prepare a feasibility analysis.Â  Tischler issued its initial proposal recommending the imposition of the fees.Â  A capital improvements plan was also drafted.Â Â  Finally, in May 2002, Tischler issued an impact fee study (the â€œTischler Reportâ€), which detailed the proposed calculation of impact fees.Â  
After several public meetings, the capital improvements plan was adopted in December 2002.Â  The impact fee ordinance was subsequently adopted on January 8, 2003, incorporating by reference the capital improvements plan and the Tischler Report.Â  The ordinance became effective February 1, 2003.
Trident commenced this action claiming the ordinance did not comply with the Act in several respects.Â  The case was referred with finality to the master-in-equity who granted Townâ€™s motion for summary judgment on several grounds, including Tridentâ€™s lack of standing, Tridentâ€™s failure to exhaust administrative remedies, lack of an appropriate remedy, and the ordinanceâ€™s compliance with the Act.Â  Trident appeals.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1.
         Does Trident have standing to maintain this action?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        2. 
         Was Trident required to exhaust administrative remedies?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        3. 
         Does the capital improvements plan substantially comply with the Act?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        4.
         Is the fee calculation in the ordinance proper?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Standing
The master found Trident had no standing to maintain this action.Â  We disagree.
An organization has standing on behalf of its members if one or more of its members will suffer an individual injury by virtue of the contested act.Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n for Protection of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Nat. Resources, 345 S.C. 594, 550 S.E.2d 287 (2001).Â  The three required elements to establish standing are:Â  an injury in fact, a causal connection, and likelihood that a favorable decision would give relief.Â  Id.Â  The record includes an affidavit by Frank Finlaw, president of Trident, stating he has paid more than $100,000 in impact fees since the ordinance was enacted.Â  In the event the ordinance was invalidated, Town could be ordered to issue refunds which would be adequate redress.Â  We conclude Trident has standing to maintain this challenge to the ordinance.
2.Â  Exhaustion of administrative remedies
The master found Trident was required to exhaust administrative remedies before bringing this action.Â  We disagree.Â  
As required by the Act, Townâ€™s ordinance provides for administrative relief. [2]Â  The ordinance provides that a refund will be issued if:Â  (a) the fees are not expended within three years of the date they were scheduled to be spent under the capital improvements plan; or (b) a building permit was subsequently denied.Â  This relief does not extend to the right to challenge the validity of the ordinance itself.Â  A party is not required to exhaust administrative remedies if the issue is one that cannot be ruled upon by the administrative body.Â  Ward v. State, 343 S.C. 14, 538 S.E.2d 245 (2000).Â  We find Trident was not required to exhaust administrative remedies before bringing this action.
3.Â  Capital improvements plan
a.Â  Incorporation of Tischler Report
Trident complains that the capital improvements plan does not comply with the Act.Â  The document entitled â€œCapital Improvements Planâ€ is simply a list of items with cost estimates for future years.Â  
Under the Act, a capital improvements plan is â€œa plan that identifies capital improvements for which development impact fees may be used as a funding source.â€Â  Â§ 6-1-920(3).Â  Impact fees may be charged only for system improvement costs that are capital improvements included in the capital improvements plan.Â  Â§ 6-1-920(8) and (22)(a).Â  The expenditure of revenue generated by impact fees is limited to capital improvements identified in the capital improvements plan.Â  Â§ 6-1-1010(B).Â  Finally, under Â§ 6-1-960(B), the capital improvements plan must contain:

(1) a general description of all existing public facilities, and their existing deficiencies, within the service area or areas of the governmental entity, a reasonable estimate of all costs, and a plan to develop the funding resources, including existing sources of revenues, related to curing the existing deficiencies including, but not limited to, the upgrading, updating, improving, expanding, or replacing of these facilities to meet existing needs and usage;
(2) an analysis of the total capacity, the level of current usage, and commitments for usage of capacity of existing public facilities, which must be prepared by a qualified professional using generally accepted principles and professional standards;
(3) a description of the land use assumptions;
(4) a definitive table establishing the specific service unit for each category of system improvements and an equivalency or conversion table establishing the ratio of a service unit to various types of land uses, including residential, commercial, agricultural, and industrial, as appropriate;
(5) a description of all system improvements and their costs necessitated by and attributable to new development in the service area, based on the approved land use assumptions, to provide a level of service not to exceed the level of service currently existing in the community or service area, unless a different or higher level of service is required by law, court order, or safety consideration;
(6) the total number of service units necessitated by and attributable to new development within the service area based on the land use assumptions and calculated in accordance with generally accepted engineering or planning criteria;
(7) the projected demand for system improvements required by new service units projected over a reasonable period of time not to exceed twenty years;
(8) identification of all sources and levels of funding available to the governmental entity for the financing of the system improvements;Â  and
(9) a schedule setting forth estimated dates for commencing and completing construction of all improvements identified in the capital improvements plan.

(emphasis added).Â  The document entitled â€œCapital Improvements Planâ€ does not meet most of these requirements since it is simply a list of items.Â  Town asserts, however, that the capital improvements plan should be read together with the Tischler Report since both were enacted with and incorporated by reference into the ordinance.Â  We agree.
Section 6-1-960(A) requires public notice and a hearing before adoption of the capital improvements plan and, under subsection (C), any change in the capital improvements plan must be approved in the same manner as the original plan.Â  The Act also provides that the capital improvements plan originate with the local planning commission.Â  The commissionâ€™s recommendations, however, â€œare not binding on the government entity, which may amend or alter the plan.â€Â  Â§ 6-1-960(A).Â  Although the Tischler Report did not originate with the planning commission, it was included in the enactment of the ordinance and was subjected to public notice and hearing.Â  Accordingly, we find the capital improvements plan was effectively amended by the Tischler Report. 
b.Â  Statutory compliance
Section 6-1-930(A)(1) provides:

Only a governmental entity that has a comprehensive plan, as provided in Chapter 29 of this title, and which complies with the requirements of this article may impose a development impact fee. Â If a governmental entity has not adopted a comprehensive plan, but has adopted a capital improvements plan which substantially complies with the requirements of Â Section 6-1-960(B), then it may impose a development impact fee.Â  

(emphasis added).Â  Town has a comprehensive plan.Â  Although Â§ 6-1-930(A)(1) seems to delineate the appropriate standard of compliance for a capital improvements plan based on whether or not the local entity has a comprehensive plan, we will not read the statute to effect an absurd result.Â  See Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994) (when construing a statute, the Court will reject meaning that would lead to an absurd result not intended by the legislature).Â  A local entity with the added safeguard of a comprehensive plan must be subject to the same, and not a more stringent, standard than a local entity without such a plan.Â  We conclude this section requires that a capital improvements plan be in substantial compliance with the requirements of Â§ 6-1-960(B), regardless of whether there is a comprehensive plan in place.Â  Accordingly, substantial compliance with the requirements for a capital improvements plan applies here.
c.Â  Statutory requirements
Trident complains there is no general description of Townâ€™s existing facilities as required in Â§ 6-1-960(B)(1).Â  The Tischler Report references specific facilities for each of the three categories (parks and recreation, fire, and municipal).Â  For example, a description of a facility under the Parks and Recreation category is:Â  â€œan extensive trails system including four miles of hiker/biker trail improvements.â€Â  This type of summary description is adequate as a general description.
Trident contends the Tischler Report failed to include â€œan analysis of total capacity, the level of current usage, and commitments for usage of capacity of existing public facilitiesâ€ as required by Â§ 6-1-960(B)(2).Â  The Tischler Report does include evaluations of its existing facilities for each category of service and indicates fees are calculated to maintain the current level of service.Â  Because Townâ€™s existing facilities are currently functioning at an acceptable level of capacity, the fees are calculated to continue this level of service by improvement at incremental stages.Â  This evaluation substantially complies with these requirements for a capital improvements plan.
Trident contends the capital improvements plan fails to identify â€œall sources and levels of funding.â€Â  The Tischler Report does note that some existing construction, such as the Public Safety Building, was purchased with the proceeds of bond issues, and calculates a credit for future bond payments.Â  Joseph Christie, the Director of Planning and Development, states in his affidavit that other funding sources were too speculative to serve as a basis for planning.Â  Although this evaluation should have been included in the Tischler Report, there is no evidence other funding was actually available but not considered.
Trident complains the capital improvements plan does not include estimated dates for commencing and completing construction.Â  The document entitled â€œCapital Improvements Planâ€ states the â€œyear neededâ€ is indicated for each capital improvement on the list of items.Â  Although there are no commencement and completion dates, this information provides an estimate of when the funds will be needed.
Trident complains the capital improvements plan includes items that cost less than $100,000 for equipment or have a useful life of less than five years in contravention of Â§ 6-1-920(2) and (18)(g).Â  The original document entitled â€œCapital Improvements Planâ€ includes such items, but they are not included in the Tischler Report which actually provides the figures used for the calculation of the impact fees.Â  The fact that these items were included in the original document has no significance in the calculation of fees.Â  
Trident contends the capital improvements plan lacks a proportionate share analysis as required by Â§ 6-1-990.Â  This section provides that â€œan impact fee imposed upon a fee payor may not exceed a proportionate share of the costs incurred by the governmental entity in providing system improvements to serve the new development.â€Â  Proportionate share is defined as the cost attributable to the new development.Â  Section 6-1-990(B) also lists specific factors to be considered including:

(1) cost of existing system improvements resulting from new development within the service area or areas;
(2) means by which existing system improvements have been financed;
(3) extent to which the new development contributes to the cost of system improvements;
(4) extent to which the new development is required to contribute to the cost of existing system improvements in the future;
(5) extent to which the new development is required to provide system improvements, without charge to other properties within the service area or areas;
(6) time and price differentials inherent in a fair comparison of fees paid at different times;Â  and
(7) availability of other sources of funding system improvements including, but not limited to, user charges, general tax levies, intergovernmental transfers, and special taxation.

The Tischler Report takes into account all these factors except (6), time and price differentials.Â  The report, however, explains that all costs are given in current dollars with no assumed inflation rate, which negates the need for time and price differentials.Â  
Although the capital improvements plan, as amended by the Tischler Report, does not comport with every criterion of the Act, we find it substantially complies with the statutory requirements.Â  
4. Calculation of fees
The Act provides for the calculation of impact fees in several provisions.Â  Section 6-1-940(1) requires that the ordinance include an explanation of the calculation of the fee.Â  Section 6-1-930(B)(2) provides that the amount of the fee â€œmust be based on actual improvement costs or reasonable estimates of the costs, supported by sound engineering studies.â€Â  Section 6-1-990 limits the impact fee to a proportionate share of the cost of improvements.Â  Finally, Â§ 6-1-980 provides:
Â§ 6-1-980.Â  Calculation of impact fees.

(A) The impact fee for each service unit may not exceed the amount determined by dividing the costs of the capital improvements by the total number of projected service units that potentially could use the capital improvement. If the number of new service units projected over a reasonable period of time is less than the total number of new service units shown by the approved land use assumptions at full development of the service area, the maximum impact fee for each service unit must be calculated by dividing the costs of the part of the capital improvements necessitated by and attributable to the projected new service units by the total projected new service units.
(B) An impact fee must be calculated in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.

In the Tischler Report, adopted by reference into Townâ€™s impact fee ordinance, fees were calculated as follows.Â  First, the report identifies three categories of impact fees:Â  parks and recreation; fire; and municipal facilities and equipment.Â  Fees for each of these categories are calculated with the â€œincremental expansion methodâ€ which uses the current level of service provided by Townâ€™s facilities and assumes expansion in regular increments.Â  This methodology essentially figures a â€œcurrent replacement costâ€ at regular intervals to pay for the increase in demand affecting each of the three categories identified above.Â  
For each category, the current replacement cost for each capital improvement is divided by Townâ€™s current number of demand units[3] to determine the â€œcost per demand unit.â€Â  The impact fee is then calculated by multiplying the cost per demand unit by the â€œdemand indicatorâ€ allocated to the type of development in question.Â  For residential development, fees are assessed per housing unit; for non-residential development, fees are assessed per 1,000 square feet or per room for motels.Â  As an example:Â  A single family detached dwelling is assumed to have 2.87 demand units.Â  The total cost per demand unit for parks and recreation is $179.27.Â  The cost per demand unit ($179.27) is multiplied by 2.87 for a fee ofÂ  $514 for a single family detached dwelling for parks and recreation.Â  This calculation is done for each category and added together for a total fee.Â  
Trident contends this calculation of fees does not comply with the requirements of the Act in the following particulars.
a. Â Actual costs or reasonable estimates
Trident claims the incremental expansion method does not use â€œactual costs or reasonable estimates supported by sound engineering studiesâ€ as required by Â§ 6-1-930(B)(2).Â  As noted above, the method used here is basically a current replacement cost approach.Â  In determining cost, the Tischler Report refers to cost information from â€œTown staffâ€ and the Marshall & Swift Valuation Service. Â References to Town staff refer to the Town engineer, Matt Halter, who is a â€œpublic engineer.â€Â  Halter testified his cost estimates were â€œbased on similar projects [Town] had done in the past or similar equipment [Town] had bought in the past, historic numbers typically.â€Â  Halter stated he gave â€œengineering estimatesâ€ for items in the capital improvements plan.Â  We find the calculation of fees was based on reasonable estimates as indicated by Townâ€™s engineer.Â  
b.Â  Sound engineering studies
Trident complains Townâ€™s cost estimates were not based on sound engineering studies as required under Â§ 6-1-930(B)(2).[4]Â  As noted above, Townâ€™s public engineer, Matt Halter, stated he gave â€œengineering estimatesâ€ for the projected costs of capital improvements.Â  The Tischler Report also references the Marshall & Swift Valuation Service, a national provider of real estate costs.[5]Â  
The Act does not specify what constitutes an â€œengineering study.â€Â  Since Town used its current facilities upon which to base estimated costs, engineering estimates are adequate.Â  Further, Trident has provided no evidence indicating cost estimates would have been different had specific engineering studies been conducted.Â  We find the use of â€œengineering estimatesâ€ and a widely accepted valuation service was adequate to meet the requirement of â€œsound engineering studies.â€
c.Â  Effect of annexation
Trident complains that in recommending impact fees, the forecasted population growth in Tischlerâ€™s initial feasibility study was skewed by growth through annexation.Â  This factor does not affect the calculation of impact fees.Â  The purpose of the feasibility study was simply to determine whether to consider enacting such fees.
d.Â  Current level of service
Trident complains Town failed to evaluate the level of service for its existing facilities.Â  â€œLevel of serviceâ€ is defined by statute as â€œa measure of the relationship between service capacity and service demand for public facilities.â€Â  Â§ 6-1-920(14).Â  Generally, it is an evaluation of how well a given service meets the publicâ€™s needs.Â  Under Â§ 6-1-930(B)(3)(b), an impact fee ordinance must â€œinclude a description of acceptable levels of service for system improvements.â€Â  
Throughout the Tischler Report, the accepted level of service for projected capital improvements is the current level of service provided by Town.Â  Joseph Christie, Townâ€™s Director of Planning and Development, testified the existing level of service was deemed adequate.Â  This evaluation was based on citizen input.Â  The Tischler Report specifically states Townâ€™s intent to â€œmaintain the current level of service . . . to accommodate new residential development and not to replace or rehabilitate existing facilities/improvements.â€Â  This description of the level of service for capital improvements as the current level of service satisfies the Act.
We find the calculation of fees in the ordinance sufficient. Further, we note Trident offers no analysis of the various factors challenged that would actually result in different fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that Trident had standing to maintain this action and did not have to exhaust administrative remedies.Â  We conclude on the merits that Townâ€™s ordinance substantially complies with the statutory requirements set forth in the Act regarding the capital improvements plan and that the calculation of fees is proper.Â  The masterâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ.,
concur.

[1] A service unit is a standardized measure of use or discharge attributable to an individual unit of development.Â  Â§ 6-1-920(20).Â  
[2]Section 6-1-1030(A) provides:Â  â€œA governmental entity which adopts a development impact fee ordinance shall provide for administrative appeals by the developer or fee payor.â€ 
[3]The report uses the 2002 population extrapolated from the 2000 census to determine demand units.Â  A residential demand unit is per person; non-residential is employees per 1,000 square feet.
[4]This section provides:Â  â€œThe amount of the development impact fee must be based on actual improvement costs or reasonable estimates of the costs, supported by sound engineering studies.â€ 
[5]Marshall & Swift is described on its website as follows:

Marshall & Swift serves a vital role in the real estate industry as the leading provider of building cost data. Our acclaimed cost manuals, desktop applications, online solutions and education programs help professionals create accurate cost valuations of commercial and residential real estate in the U.S., U.S. territories, Canada and select foreign cities worldwide.

http://www.marshallswift.com/ms-about.aspx.

title: Home Port Rentals v. Moore
description: The Court granted a writ of certiorari to review Home Port Rentals, Inc. v. Moore, 359 S.C. 230, 597 S.E.2d 810 (Ct. The Court affirmed as modified, holding that the ten-year limitation period on judgment execution cannot be tolled for time during which a judgment debtor is out of state.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Home Port Rentals, Inc., Petitioner,
v.
Roger Moore, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26182
Heard June 8, 2006 - Filed July 10, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
M. Dawes Cooke, Jr. and Phillip S. Ferderigos, both of Barnwell, Whaley, Patterson & Helms, of Charleston, for Petitioner.
Thomas W. Bunch II and L. Jefferson Davis IV, both of Robinson, McFadden & Moore, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ACTING JUSTICE KING:Â  This is a judgment-execution case.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of Roger Moore (Respondent) against Home Port Rentals, Inc. (Petitioner), holding that South Carolinaâ€™s ten-year limitations period for execution[1] is not tolled for time during which a judgment debtor is out of state.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Home Port Rentals, Inc. v. Moore, 359 S.C. 230, 597 S.E.2d 810 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This Court granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
On March 20, 1989, the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina entered judgment against Respondent and in favor of Petitioner.Â  Petitioner thereafter tried to locate Respondent in order to execute on the judgment, but could not do so until January 1999.Â  
On July 14, 2000, Petitioner filed an action for declaratory judgment in the circuit court.Â  Petitioner sought a declaration that the 1989 judgment was still effective, arguing that the ten-year limitations period for execution had been tolled for the time during which Respondent was absent from South Carolina - the entire eleven-year period following entry of the judgment.Â  The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and the circuit court granted summary judgment to Respondent.Â  The court held that the 1989 judgment was no longer valid because it was more than ten years old.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.
ISSUE

Whether the Court of Appeals erred in holding that the 1989 judgment is no longer valid because it is more than ten years old.

ANALYSIS
The judgment of the federal district court was enrolled, and therefore became a South Carolina judgment, when it was entered on March 20, 1989.Â  
Under the Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act,[2] the 1989 judgment of the federal district court is a â€œforeign judgment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-910(1) (2005).Â  Ordinarily, a foreign judgment must be enrolled in this state in order to be effective as a South Carolina judgment.Â  Under federal law, however, a judgment of the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina is effectively a South Carolina judgment.Â  The United States Code provides:

Every judgment rendered by a district court within a State shall be a lien on the property located in such
State in the same manner, to the same extent and under
the same conditions as a judgment of a court of general
jurisdiction in such State, and shall cease to be a lienin the same manner and time.

28 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1962 (West 1994).
Consequently, South Carolina law determines the date on which the federal courtâ€™s judgment became a lien in South Carolina.
South Carolina Code section 15-35-810 applies the federal statute and provides that a judgment of the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina 

shall constitute a lien upon the real estate of the
judgment debtor situate[d] in any county in this State in which the judgment or transcript thereof
is entered upon the book of abstracts of judgments and duly indexed, the lien to begin from the time of
such entry on the book of abstracts and indices and to continue for a period of ten years from the date of
such final judgment ....Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-810 (2005).
As the Court of Appeals held, therefore, the district courtâ€™s judgment became effective when it was entered on March 20, 1989.
As stated above, Petitioner filed this declaratory-judgment action on July 14, 2000, more than ten years after entry of the 1989 judgment.Â  South Carolina Code section 15-39-30 provides:

Executions may issue upon final judgments or decrees at any time within ten years from the date of the original
 entry thereof and shall have active energy during such period, without any renewal or renewals thereof, and
 this whether any return may or may not have been made during such period on such executions.

This Court has consistently held that under the statute, a judgment becomes stale and a judgment lien is extinguished after ten years.Â  See, e.g., Garrison v. Owens, 258 S.C. 442, 446-47, 189 S.E.2d 31, 33 (1972); Hardee v. Lynch, 212 S.C. 6, 46 S.E.2d 179 (1948).Â  In so holding, the Court has reasoned, â€œA judgment lien is purely statutory, its duration as fixed by the legislature may not be prolonged by the courts and the bringing of an action to enforce the lien will not preserve it beyond the time fixed by statute, if such time expires before the action is tried.â€Â  Garrison, 258 S.C. at 446-47, 189 S.E.2d at 33 (citations omitted).
According to Petitioner, the legislature has provided for the prolonging of the existence of the judgment and lien in at least one situation.Â  Relying on South Carolina Code section 15-3-30,[3] Petitioner argues the ten-year period provided by section 15-39-30 may be tolled for time that a judgment debtor spends out of the state.Â  We disagree.
Section 15-3-30 provides:

If when a cause of action shall accrue against any person he shall be out of the State, such action may
be commenced within the terms in this chapter respectively limited after the return of such person
into this State. And if, after such cause of action shall have accrued, such person shall depart from and reside
out of this State or remain continuously absent there from for the space of one year or more, the time of his absence
shall not be deemed or taken as any part of the time limited for the commencement of such action. 

We agree with the Court of Appeals that the statute does not apply here.Â  Unlike the Court of Appeals, however, we look no further than the language of section 15-3-30 to reach this conclusion.Â  The plain wording[4] of section 15-3-30 provides that the statute applies to the accrual of a â€œcause of actionâ€ and the statutory time period within which to bring the action.Â  The statute does not refer to the statutory time period within which to execute an already obtained judgment.Â  Contrary to Petitionerâ€™s argument, the right to execute on a judgment does not constitute a cause of action.Â  Indeed, execution is not initiated by bringing an action.Â  
Consequently, section 15-3-30 cannot operate to toll the ten-year execution period.Â  While the limitations period for bringing an action may be tolled if the defendant is absent from the state, the period for executing an already obtained judgment may not.Â  The decision of the Court of Appeals is therefore
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-30 (2005).
[2]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-35-900 through -960 (2005).
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-30 (2005).
[4] â€œUnder our general rules of construction, the words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statute's operation.â€Â  State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264, 268, 559 S.E.2d 847, 849 (2003).Â

title: State v. Bryant
description: We granted Petitioner a writ of certiorari to review State v. Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 589 S.E.2d 775 (Ct. App. 2003), in which the court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s admission of Petitionerâ€™s two prior firearms convictions.  We reverse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent.
v.
Thomas Bryant, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Richland County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26183
Heard November 15, 2005 - Filed July 17, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  We granted Petitioner a writ of certiorari to review State v. Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 589 S.E.2d 775 (Ct. App. 2003), in which the court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s admission of Petitionerâ€™s two prior firearms convictions.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner has been confined to a wheelchair for over twentyÂ  years due to a car accident.Â  On July 22, 1999, he was visiting the Bottoms Up strip club, where he met the victim, Daniel Fletcher Austin.Â  At approximately 3:30 a.m., the two left the club together to go back to Petitionerâ€™s hotel room.Â  
Between 3:30 and 4:00 a.m., as he was leaving his room to go to work, Kevin Hawkins saw Petitioner alone in the corridor.Â  Petitioner asked Hawkins to get him help because he said he had been injured in a physical altercation.Â  Hawkins informed the front desk clerk of Petitionerâ€™s claims.Â  As the clerk called the sheriffâ€™s department, she heard shots.Â  Immediately before calling the sheriff, the clerk testified she had given Austin a key to Petitionerâ€™s room.Â  
The police arrived and found Austin lying in the breezeway shot six times and bleeding.Â  A stand-off ensued between the police and Petitioner which lasted 20-25 minutes. The stand-off ended when a SWAT team rushed Petitionerâ€™s room and found Petitioner on the floor with a self-inflicted gunshot wound to his stomach.Â  
Petitioner was convicted of murder and the unlawful possession of a weapon by a convicted felon.Â  He was sentenced to life without parole for the murder and five years concurrent for the weapons charge.Â  
ISSUE Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Did the circuit court err in admitting Petitionerâ€™s priorÂ  firearms convictions?

LAW/ANALYSISÂ  
At trial, prior to Petitioner testifying, the State sought to introduce evidence that Petitioner had previously been convicted of voluntary manslaughter in 1984, shoplifting in 1992, a bad check charge in 1994, possession of a unlawful weapon by a convicted felon in 1997, and pointing and presenting a firearm in 1998.Â  Petitioner did not object to the admission of the shoplifting or bad check convictions.Â  He argued, however, that the manslaughter conviction should be excluded because it was more than ten years old.Â  As to the two weapons convictions, Petitioner argued they did not have anything to do with truthfulness and thus their probative value was low.Â  He further argued that their similarity to the current charges caused their admission to be highly prejudicial.Â  
The State contends the convictions were offered to impeach Petitioner and to show â€œthe defendant continues to get in trouble even after 1990.Â  Every two years, he commits at least two crimes.â€Â  The trial judge allowed the firearms convictions to be introduced, and although the manslaughter conviction itself was not introduced, Petitioner stipulated he had been convicted of a violent crime in 1984.Â  
The court of appeals affirmed Petitionerâ€™s convictions in a 2:1 decision.Â  Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 589 S.E.2d 775.Â  Relying on State v. Green, 338 S.C. 428, 527 S.E.2d 827 (2000), the majority reviewed the trial courtâ€™s statements as a whole and concluded that the trial court had an appropriate reason to admit the evidence â€œbased on [the trial courtâ€™s] belief the testimony could lead to an inference [Petitioner] was unworthy of credibility because of his prior convictions.â€ Bryant,Â  356 S.C. at 491, 589 S.E.2d at 776.
Noting the importance of â€œ[Petitioner's] testimony to his defense, and the state's burden of discounting his testimony to prove the elements of murder,â€ the Court of Appeals nonetheless held the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in admitting Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions to impeach his credibility.Â  Id. at 492, 589 S.E.2d at 779.Â  Judge Beatty dissented and stated he believed the prior convictions were improper character evidence and should not have been admitted.Â  Id. at 496, 589 S.E.2d at 781.Â  He also concluded that the admission was not harmless because there was not overwhelming evidence of Petitionerâ€™s guilt.Â  Id.Â  
This Court has held that a trial judge must conduct a balancing test to determine whether remote convictions are admissible under Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 626, 525 S.E.2d 246, 248 (2000).Â  Rule 609(b) creates a presumption that remote convictions are inadmissible and places the burden on the State to overcome this presumption. Id. When considering whether to admit prior convictions, a trial judge should consider the following factors: 

  
    
      
        (1)
         The impeachment value of the prior crime;
      
      
        (2)
         The point in time of the conviction and the witness's subsequent history;
      
      
        (3)
         The similarity of the past crime and the charged crime;
      
      
        (4) 
         The importance of the defendant's testimony; and
      
      
        (5)
         The centrality of the credibility issue.
      
    
  

Id. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248.Â  After the trial court conducts the balancing test, the judge must make a determination and articulate, on the record, the specific reasons for his ruling. Â Id.Â  Specifically, the trial judge must articulate why the probative value of the prior conviction outweighs its prejudicial effect.Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 59-60, 609 S.E.2d 520 (2005). [1]Â  
Under Rule 609(a)(2), SCRE, if a crime is viewed as one involving dishonesty, the court must admit the prior conviction because, prior convictions involving dishonesty or false statement must be admitted regardless of their probative value or prejudicial effect.Â  Thus, Petitionerâ€™s convictions for shoplifting and writing bad checks were properly admitted and Petitioner does not dispute this.Â  The issue is whether the prior firearms convictions involve dishonesty or false statements so as to be admissible without weighing the probative value of their admission with its prejudicial effect.Â  
Violations of narcotics laws are generally not probative ofÂ  truthfulness.Â  See State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 552 S.E.2d 300 S.C. (2001) (citing State v. Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248 (2000)).Â  Furthermore, a conviction for robbery, burglary, theft, and drug possession, beyond the basic crime itself, is not probative of truthfulness.Â  United States v. Smith, 181 F.Supp.2d 904 (N.D. Ill. 2002).Â Â  Likewise, firearms violations also are not generally probative of truthfulness.Â Â  Accordingly, Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions do not involve dishonesty and their probative value should have been weighed against their prejudicial effect prior to their admission pursuant to Rule 609(a)(1).
In admitting the prior firearms convictions, the trial judge noted that â€œthe fact that he may tend to get in trouble from time to time, while it has a certain amount of prejudice in it, also, does include that issue of whether or not he's worthy of belief.â€Â  The trial judge did not address the similarity of the prior convictions to the current charges as required by Colf.Â  Additionally, we note that when the prior offense is similar to the offense for which the defendant is on trial, the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant from impeachment by that prior offense weighs against its admission. See e.g., Colf, 337 S.C. at 628, 525 S.E.2d at 249.Â  Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions had nothing to do with Petitionerâ€™s credibility and, their admission was more prejudicial than probative, especially in light of the offenses for which he was on trial. Accordingly, we hold the trial court erred in admitting Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions. 
The State, however, contends even if the trial court erred, the admission of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions was harmless.Â  We disagree.Â  
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial. In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result. State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991). Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where a defendantâ€™s guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached. Â State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989).Â  The circumstances of each individual case are to be considered. 
Additionally, â€œthis Court has placed great emphasis on the importance of a defendantâ€™s right to assert self-defense when there is any evidence to support it.â€Â  State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 235, 589 S.E.2d 1, 5 (2003) (emphasis added).Â Â  In acknowledgement of this important right, our Court has made every effort to assure that the burden remains on the State to disprove self-defense.Â  See State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002); State v. Addison, 343 S.C. 290, 540 S.E.2d 449 (2000); State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 500 S.E.2d 489 (1998). Â Â Â 
In this case, Petitionerâ€™s defense was that he acted in self-defense, and this hinged entirely on his own testimony. Â Moreover, the only witnesses to the shooting were Petitioner and the victim.Â  Although, the record contains evidence which may undermine Petitionerâ€™s self-defense theory, the record also contains evidence which supports Petitionerâ€™s self-defense theory.Â  Â Therefore, the State should not be allowed to attack the defendantâ€™s credibility with inadmissible prior convictions; especially where the Petitionerâ€™s credibility was essential to his defense.Â  Accordingly, we hold the improper admission of Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions was not harmless.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the improper admission of Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions was erroneous and does not qualify as harmless error.Â  Accordingly, we hold his murder conviction should be
REVERSED.[2]
MOORE, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice James C. Williams, concur.Â  BURNETT, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
BURNETT, J.:Â  I agree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion the trial court erred in admitting Petitionerâ€™s prior firearms convictions.Â  However, I disagree with the majorityâ€™s harmless error analysis.Â  Therefore, I respectfully dissent.
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 63, 584 S.E.2d 893, 897 (2003).Â  The materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989).Â  Error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the verdict obtained.Â  Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992).Â  Where a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 531, 466 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1996).Â  
To establish self defense: (1) the defendant must be without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the defendant must have been in actual imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or he must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) the defendant must show that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the belief that he was actually in imminent danger and that the circumstances were such as would warrant a person of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike the fatal blow in order to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss of his life; and (4) the defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.Â  State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 344-45, 520 S.E.2d 319, 321-22 (1999); State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994). 
At trial, Petitioner argued he acted in self defense and this defense hinged entirely on his own testimony.Â  In my opinion, Petitionerâ€™s exculpatory story of self defense is not plausible.Â  
Petitioner testified he was living at Days Inn, where he met the victim, Austin, earlier in the week.Â  He testified on July 22, 1999, he went to Bottoms Up, a strip club, where he met Austin.Â  He and Austin had several alcoholic drinks during the evening.Â  Austin repeatedly asked Petitioner if he had any â€œweedâ€ or knew where to find any â€œweed,â€ but Petitioner repeatedly told Austin he did not.Â  Around 3:30 a.m. Petitioner left the club to go back to the hotel and Austin followed him.Â  The two men had a fist fight in the parking lot of Bottoms Up, and Petitioner testified Austin did not possess a weapon during the fight.Â  He and Austin continued towards the hotel, but they got into another fist fight during which Petitioner fell out of his wheelchair.Â  Austin kicked Petitioner in the face and eventually helped him back into his wheelchair.Â  The two men then proceeded to Petitionerâ€™s room, where they again had an altercation in front of the room.Â  Petitioner fell out of his wheelchair during this incident, and Austin helped him back into the wheelchair.Â  At this point, Austin left and went to the hotel desk clerk to get a room key.
Kevin Hawkins testified he saw Petitioner alone in the corridor between 3:30 a.m. and 4:00 a.m.Â  Petitioner asked Hawkins to tell the front desk clerk he had been robbed and needed help.Â  Hawkins testified Petitioner had a scrape on his nose and he informed the front desk of Petitionerâ€™s request.
Petitioner testified as he opened the door to his room, Austin reappeared.Â  Austin then followed Petitioner inside, closed the door, and demanded â€œweed.â€Â  Petitioner testified he thought Austin would kill him and that another person was with Austin.Â  He further testified Austin was not armed.
Petitioner then went to the nightstand and retrieved a loaded pistol.Â  He shot Austin six times and Austin fell, got back up, and ran out of the room.Â  Petitioner then went to the dresser and retrieved a loaded shotgun.Â  He went into the breezeway where he saw Austin leaning against the wall.[3]Â  Petitioner fired the shotgun five times because he thought Austin had not been previously hit.Â  He then went back into the room, reloaded both guns, and shot out into the hallway from the room.Â  Petitioner eventually shot himself in the stomach before being apprehended by police after a stand-off.Â  
In my opinion, Petitionerâ€™s guilt was conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion could have been reached.Â  Petitioner testified that after he shot the unarmed Austin six times, Austin ran out of the room.Â  See State v. Light, 363 S.C. 325, 610 S.E.2d 504 (Ct. App. 2005) (unarmed victim did not pose a threat to armed defendant and the defendant could not have reasonably believed she did.)Â  Further, Petitioner followed Austin out into the hallway and continued shooting, even though he was not sure it was Austin in the hallway.Â  
Significantly, the ballistics evidence does not support Petitionerâ€™s claims.Â  The Stateâ€™s ballistics experts testified the pistol shots were fired through the hotel room door.Â  Further, an officer testified he did not see any blood in the hotel room which is inconsistent with Austin having fallen after being shot several times while in the hotel room.Â  
Even though the trial court erred in admitting Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions, the error was harmless because the evidence fails in any respect to support Petitionerâ€™s self-defense theory.Â  A reasonably prudent person would not have believed Petitioner had to shoot Austin repeatedly through a door, reload, follow him into the hallway, and again shoot him in the hallway in order to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss of his life.Â Â  Accordingly, the admission of the prior firearms convictions was harmless.

[1]Although Colf involved the admission of remote convictions under Rule 609(b), the â€œ[Court of Appeals] has implicitly recognized the value of these factors in making such a determination under Rule 609(a)(1), and urged the trial bench to not only articulate its ruling, but to also provide the basis for it, thereby clearly and easily informing the appellate courts that a meaningful balancing of the probative value and the prejudicial effect has taken place as required by Rule 609(a)(1).â€Â  State v. Martin, 347 S.C. 522, 530, 556 S.E.2d 706, 710 (Ct. App. 2001) (internal quotation marks omitted).
[2]At trial, Petitioner admitted he was guilty of unlawful possession of a weapon by a convicted felon and his self-defense argument went to only the murder charge. Accordingly, his conviction for unlawful possession of a weapon stands. 
[3]Petitioner testified he was not sure if the person in the breezeway was Austin.

title: Delahoussaye v. State
description: In this PCR case, the Court affirmed that the claim was properly brought under the PCR Act, but reversed the grant of relief finding respondent was not entitled to credit for time served for federal  crimes committed after he escaped from South Carolina's custody.
text:
Delahoussaye


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        
Ralph Delahoussaye, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
        
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26184
Submitted May 24, 2006 - Filed July 17, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to respondent Ralph Delahoussaye.Â  We affirm in part, and reverse in part.
FACTS
On March 9, 1976, a jury convicted respondent of armed robbery, and the trial court sentenced him to 25 years imprisonment.Â  This Court affirmed respondentâ€™s conviction on November 12, 1976.Â  State v. Delahoussaye, Op. No. 76-MO-106 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 12, 1976).Â  Four days later, on November 16, 1976, respondent escaped from the custody of the South Carolina Department of Corrections
(SCDOC).
While an escapee, respondent committed the federal crimes of conspiracy to kidnap, conspiracy to transport a stolen motor vehicle interstate, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony.Â  He was sentenced to 45 years in federal district court in Georgia on February 4, 1977.Â  At the sentencing, the trial court stated:

Now you all[1] have difficulties with the State of South Carolina as to the charges you were serving and have not yet completed.Â  There are other charges pending against you that have not yet been resolved.Â  The sentence that this Court imposes upon each of you today is separate and distinct of all other sentences that have been imposed or that may be imposed by any other court, Federal or State.Â  I say that so there wonâ€™t be any misunderstanding about that.

The SCDOC issued a detainer against respondent on August 7, 1979.[2]Â Â  After being paroled from federal prison, respondent returned to the SCDOCâ€™s custody on February 2, 2002.Â  The SCDOC calculated his projected max-out date for the 25-year armed robbery sentence as August 9, 2015.
In June 2002, respondent filed for PCR seeking credit for the time he served while in federal custody. Â After a hearing, the PCR court rejected the Stateâ€™s argument that, pursuant to Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000), this is an administrative matter not properly heard in PCR court.Â  In addition, the PCR court granted respondent relief and ordered that respondentâ€™s sentence â€œbe recalculated so that he is given credit for time spent in federal custody since August 7, 1979.â€Â  
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1. 
         Did the PCR court err in finding that respondentâ€™s claim, involving credit for time served in another jurisdiction, was appropriate for
          PCR? Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        2.
         Did the PCR court err in finding that respondentâ€™s time served in federal custody, for crimes committed after his escape from South Carolinaâ€™s custody, entitled him to credit on his original South Carolina armed robbery sentence?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Propriety of Claim under PCR Act
The State argues that the PCR court erred in allowing respondentâ€™s claim to be asserted under the PCR Act because it involves service credit which, pursuant to Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000), is the type of claim that should be reviewed under the Administrative Procedures Act
(APA).
In Al-Shabazz, this Court held that under the PCR statute, PCR is proper only when the applicant mounts a collateral attack challenging the validity of his conviction or sentence. Â Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 367, 527 S.E.2d at 749 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-20(a)). Â Nonetheless, the Al-Shabazz Court noted â€œtwo non-collateral matters specifically listed in Section 17-27-20(a)(5)â€ that are cognizable under the PCR Act:Â  â€œthe claim that an applicantâ€™s sentence has expired and the claim that an applicantâ€™s probation, parole, or conditional release has been unlawfully revoked.â€[3]Â  Id. at 368, 527 S.E.2d at 749.
As for the majority of non-collateral matters, however, Al-Shabazz stated that these claims generally would be decided first by the SCDOCâ€™s internal grievance system and then would be subject to review under the APA.Â  Id. at 369, 527 S.E.2d at 750.Â  Specifically, the Court noted that â€œ[t]hese administrative matters typically arise in two ways: (1) when an inmate is disciplined and punishment is imposed and (2) when an inmate believes prison officials have erroneously calculated his sentence, sentence-related credits, or custody status.â€Â  Id.
The PCR court found that the instant case was distinguishable from Al-Shabazz, which concerned discretionary good-time credits, because this case involved â€œday-for-day time actually servedâ€ by the inmate.Â  In addition, the PCR court found that where a case involves the expiration of a sentence, Al-Shabazz specifically allowed this type of claim under the PCR Act.Â  
We agree with the PCR court that respondentâ€™s case encompasses a claim that his sentence had expired.[4] Â Therefore, this matter was appropriately filed pursuant to the PCR statute. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-20(a)(5); Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 368, 527 S.E.2d at 749.Â  
Accordingly, we affirm the PCR courtâ€™s ruling on this issue.
2.Â  Credit For Federal Time Served After An Escape
The State also argues that when an inmate escapes from the SCDOCâ€™s custody, subsequently commits a crime in another jurisdiction while an escapee, and serves time for the subsequent crime, the inmate should not be entitled to credit for the time served simply because the SCDOC has issued a detainer.Â  The PCR court, however, found that this Courtâ€™s decision in Robinson v. State, 329 S.C. 65, 495 S.E.2d 433 (1998), clearly stated that a South Carolina convict may receive credit for the time that he is incarcerated in another jurisdiction from the time that a detainer is issued by the SCDOC.Â  We agree with the State that because Robinson did not involve an escapee, it is inapplicable to the instant case.
In Robinson v. State, Robinson had been found guilty of accessory after the fact of a felony in South Carolina state court in 1989; he was sentenced to ten years imprisonment.Â  He appealed his conviction and was released on appeal bond.Â  Later in 1989, he was arrested in Chicago on federal RICO charges.Â  He was subsequently convicted and sentenced to six years in prison.Â  Then, in August 1992, he was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment on additional, gang-related federal charges. Â The federal sentences were ordered to run concurrently with Robinsonâ€™s state sentence.Â  329 S.C. at 66-67, 495 S.E.2d at 434. Â Robinsonâ€™s state conviction was affirmed by this Court in September 1991 (which was in between his federal court convictions). Â See State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 409 S.E.2d 404 (1991), cert. denied, 503 U.S. 937 (1992).
Robinson filed for PCR seeking to obtain credit in South Carolina for time served in federal custody from the date his conviction was affirmed. Â Robinson had been in federal custody from the date of his 1989 arrest until January 18, 1995, when he was admitted to, but deemed absent with leave from, the SCDOC.Â  The PCR court granted Robinson credit for time served from the date his South Carolina conviction was affirmed. Â Robinson v. State, 329 S.C. at 67, 495 S.E.2d at 434.
This Court reversed explaining that because the federal sentences had been ordered to run concurrent with the South Carolina sentence, â€œthe Bureau of Prisons should have delivered Robinson into South Carolina custody so that the federal courtâ€™s imposition of a concurrent sentence could be satisfied.â€Â  Id. at 71, 495 S.E.2d at 436.Â  However, the Court also stated thatÂ Â  while a â€œconvict is subject to a South Carolina detainer, he is constructively in South Carolina custody. Â As a result, a convict will receive credit for time spent in another jurisdiction while subject to a South Carolina detainer.â€ Â Id. at 71, 495 S.E.2d at 436-37.Â  Therefore, the Court held that he should have been given credit for time served since January 18, 1995 (the date he was constructively admitted to the SCDOC). Â Id. at 71, 495 S.E.2d at 437.
Respondent argues the rule of Robinson applies to his case despite the fact that he escaped from state custody.Â  Specifically, respondent maintains that the lodging of a detainer significantly harms a federal inmateâ€™s status, and these consequences occur â€œregardless of whether the person escaped.â€Â  Thus, respondent contends that the PCR court correctly applied Robinson.Â  We disagree.Â  Because Robinson was lawfully out on appeal bond, he was entitled to the credit.Â  Here, however, respondent escaped from the SCDOCâ€™s custody.Â  Under South Carolina law, it is clear respondentâ€™s status as an escapee distinguishes this case from the Robinson rule.
In Oglesby v. Leeke, 263 S.C. 283, 210 S.E.2d 232 (1974), we stated that â€œ[a]s a general rule, a sentence can be satisfied only by death, service of the required time, or relief therefrom by competent authority.â€Â  Id. at 287, 210 S.E.2d at 234.Â  There, Oglesby had been sentenced to three years for housebreaking and larceny; he escaped approximately five months after his sentence began.Â  Subsequently, he committed a crime in New York and served time there.Â  While serving the New York sentence, a detainer was filed requesting a hold for South Carolina.Â  Oglesby refused to waive extradition, but extradition was eventually granted, and he returned to prison in South Carolina to complete service of the three-year sentence.Â  Id. at 285-86, 210 S.E.2d at 233.
This Court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s denial of â€œcredit for any of the time he was away during his escape.â€Â  Id. at 286, 210 S.E.2d at 233.Â  Significantly, we held that Oglesbyâ€™s escape â€œtolled the running of the sentence he was then serving and the time of his imprisonment under that sentence did not again begin to run until his return to the South Carolina prison.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, we observed that Oglesbyâ€™s:

[E]ntire absence was because of his escape and his resistance to efforts of the State of South Carolina to effect his return for the service of his sentence. Â It is undisputed that no part of his absence or imprisonment in New York was in execution of the South Carolina sentence.

Id. at 286-87, 210 S.E.2d at 233-34 (emphasis added).Â  
We hold that the rule of Oglesby was not modified by this Courtâ€™s decision in Robinson and therefore directly applies to respondentâ€™s case.Â  Here, as in Oglesby, respondentâ€™s entire absence from the SCDOCâ€™s custody was because of his escape.Â  Furthermore, given the federal trial judgeâ€™s comments regarding respondentâ€™s â€œdifficulties with the State of South Carolinaâ€ and that the federal sentence was â€œseparate and distinct of all other sentences that have been imposed or that may be imposed by any other court,â€ respondent cannot assert that his federal sentence was intended to run concurrently with his South Carolina sentence.
Moreover, because we have previously distinguished a rule regarding service credit based on whether the inmateâ€™s status was non-escapee versus escapee, it is consistent with South Carolina case law that the Robinson rule should not be applied to an escapee. Â Compare State v. Dozier, 263 S.C. 267, 210 S.E.2d 225 (1974) (holding that where a non-escapee is imprisoned in another state while contesting extradition, he is entitled to credit on any subsequent South Carolina sentence) with Kephart v. State, 277 S.C. 395, 289 S.E.2d 402 (1982) (holding that escapeeâ€™s time spent imprisoned in Pennsylvania contesting extradition should not be credited toward his remaining armed robbery sentence in South Carolina).[5]
Finally, we note that several other states have also ruled an escapee cannot be credited with time served in another jurisdiction on a subsequent crime.Â  See, e.g., Woodson v. State, 383 N.E.2d 1096 (Ind. Ct. App. 1978); Williams v. State, 280 N.W.2d 406 (Iowa 1979); State ex rel. Linehan v. Wood, 397 N.W.2d 341 (Minn. 1986); Commonwealth ex rel. Goins v. Rundle, 192 A.2d 720 (Pa.), cert. denied, 375 U.S. 959 (1963); Carter v. State, 523 S.W.2d 639 (Tenn. Crim. App. 1975).Â  
Indeed, â€œ[i]t would be a novel rule which would allow a sentenced criminal, by the simple expedient of escape, to select the state in which he wishes to serve his incarceration.â€Â  Williams, 280 N.W.2d at 408; see also Carter, 523 S.W.2d at 640 (â€œService of jail time in another jurisdiction during a fugitive status certainly does not double as service of the punishment escaped from.â€).
In sum, we find the PCR court erred by applying Robinson and ordering that respondentâ€™s sentence be recalculated by the SCDOC.Â  Because respondentâ€™s escape â€œtolled the running of the sentence he was then serving,â€ the SCDOC correctly calculated that his 25-year armed robbery sentence originally imposed in 1976 â€œdid not again begin to run until his return to the South Carolina prisonâ€ in 2002.Â  Oglesby, 263 S.C. at 287, 210 S.E.2d at 234. 
Accordingly, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief to respondent.Â  See Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (the Court will reverse if the PCR courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law).
CONCLUSION
Based on the above reasons, the PCR courtâ€™s finding that respondent properly pursued this action under the PCR Act is affirmed.Â  However, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s ruling that respondent was entitled to credit on his South Carolina armed robbery sentence for federal time served after he escaped from the SCDOCâ€™s custody.
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Respondent had a co-defendant in federal court.Â  
[2] The August 7, 1979, letter indicated respondent was â€œwanted to complete the remainder of the 25-year sentence from which he escaped on November 16, 1976,â€ in addition to being wanted for other outstanding charges related to his escape. Â Eventually, the detainer that was specifically related to the unresolved charges was considered â€œvoidâ€ for lack of prosecution, but a â€œholdâ€ was continued due to respondentâ€™s 25-year sentence for the armed robbery conviction.
[3]Â  Section 17-27-20 lists who may institute a PCR action and specifically states that â€œ[a]ny person who has been convicted of, or sentenced for, a crime and who claims: Â â€¦ (5) That his sentence has expired, his probation, parole or conditional release unlawfully revoked, or he is otherwise unlawfully held in custody or other restraintâ€ may bring a claim under the PCR Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-20(a)(5) (2003) (emphasis added).
[4] We note the SCDOC released respondent from its custody after the PCR court granted him relief (but prior to the State filing its appeal).Â  Thus, under these particular facts, it is clear to us respondentâ€™s claim regarding credit for approximately 23 years of federal time actually served indeed was a claim that his 25-year South Carolina sentence had expired.
[5] The Legislature has also made distinctions regarding service credit based on an inmateâ€™s escapee status. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-40 (1976) (statute for computation of time served by prisoners provides that full credit shall be given for time served prior to trial and sentencing, except that credit for time served shall not be given â€œwhen the prisoner at the time he was imprisoned prior to trial was an escapee from another penal institutionâ€).Â

Heard May 24, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, and Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Isaac McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: Â This is a capital case.Â  Roberts was convicted of the murder of two Beaufort County Sheriffâ€™s Deputies and was sentenced to death.Â  The sole issue he raises on appeal is whether the trial court erred in requiring him to remain present during the sentencing phase of his trial.Â  We affirm the convictions and sentence.Â  
FACTS
In January 2002, Roberts lived in a trailer owned by Brenda Smith on Riley Road in Beaufort County.Â  Also residing at the trailer were Smithâ€™s husband, Isaac, and Robertsâ€™ wife Nzuri.Â  At the time of the crime in this case, a girl named Kimberly Blake, with whom Roberts had an infant daughter, was also staying there.Â  On January 8, 2002, Kimberly Blake asked her friend, Strawberry Washington, to call police to come to the house to assist her in leaving because Roberts had hit her.Â  Beaufort County Sheriffâ€™s Deputies Dyke Coursen and Dana Tate responded.Â  According to Kimberly Blake, when police arrived, Roberts hid in the bedroom closet with his rifle.Â  He gave Kimberly the okay to go out of the bedroom.Â  She left the bedroom and Brenda Smith gave the officers permission to search the bedroom.Â  Officers Coursen and Tate went into the bedroom.Â  Smith and Blake heard gunshots.Â  Blake ran outside and down the road.Â  She was joined shortly after by Roberts coming through the woods with a gun in his hands.Â  Roberts stated, â€œI just killed those two white bitches and Iâ€™m going to say it was self-defense.â€Â  Blake left Roberts and returned to the scene to talk to police.
When backup officers responded to the scene, they found officers Coursen and Tate dead; Coursen had suffered six gunshot wounds, Tate had seven.Â  Roberts was subsequently found hiding in the mud under a bridge with a shoulder and hip wound.Â  Roberts was arrested.Â  At the time, he had a black fanny pack carrying ammunition for an M-14 assault rifle, a cell phone and a knife.Â  Police subsequently found a rifle magazine and an SKS assault rifle in the area in which Roberts had fled.Â  The bullets and casings recovered from the victims and the scene of the crime were conclusively matched to the assault rifle.Â Â Â  
Roberts was charged with capital murder.Â  At the guilt or innocence phase of trial, he chose to represent himself.Â  However, two attorneys remained as stand-by counsel to assist him at trial.Â  While the jury was deliberating, Roberts indicated to the trial court that if the jury returned a guilty verdict, he did not intend to participate at sentencing.Â  He also indicated he did not want his stand-by attorneys to present a defense.Â  Roberts indicated that if the trial court required him to be present at the sentencing hearing, he would be unruly and would have to be restrained.Â  
The jury convicted Roberts of two counts of murder.Â  Roberts advised the court he did not intend to offer any mitigating evidence and expressed his desire to absent himself from the sentencing; he indicated he would probably be unruly if required to be present.Â  Stand-by counsel conferred with Roberts and then advised the court as follows:

He says that he doesnâ€™t agree to any changes in his status as attorney of record, and that if the court makes any change, theyâ€™ll have to do it on their own motion. . . and that if the judge - if the attorneys on stand-by are to perform in any capacity, the judge will have to order that on his own motion. . . Â He says that he doesnâ€™t want to be present in this courtroom in order to hear the evidence in the second phase.Â  And that if the judge - but he does not intend to disrupt the proceedings. . . but if the judge determines that he should be in one of the side rooms . . . thatâ€™s a decision that his honor will have to make himself.Â  He says that he is withdrawing from any further discussion with the court. . . . he does not intend to cooperate with stand-by counsel, to bring any witnesses. . . .

The trial court was concerned with Robertsâ€™ decision, but was also disturbed that to appoint counsel to represent Roberts at sentencing might compromise his right to proceed pro se.Â  Roberts continued to maintain that he did not intend to confront any witnesses, and did not want to see the witnesses.Â  He persisted in advising the court that if forced to remain present, he would be disruptive.Â  As neither party could point to specific case law governing the circumstances, the court determined the best course of action was to proceed with Roberts present in the courtroom, with the condition that if he became disruptive, the trial judge would take such action as necessary.Â  Roberts indicated his desire that counsel not represent him in any way, but ultimately decided counsel could remain as stand-by counsel to object to the introduction of improper evidence.Â  
The sentencing proceeded with Roberts seated at counsel table.Â  As soon as the first witness was sworn, Roberts stood and began to chant aloud, â€œBlessed be Yahweh, El Shaddai, Jehova, God Almighty, the God of Abraham, Isaac, Ishmael, Jacob, and Jesus.â€Â  He was told by the court to be seated, and when he continued chanting, he was removed and a brief hearing was held in the hearing room at the back of the courtroom.Â  Roberts was brought back into the courtroom and once again began chanting when the witness began to testify.Â  The jury was removed, and Roberts was placed in a conference room at the back of the courtroom which had a glass partition to allow him to hear and see into the courtroom.Â  He was initially restrained, but the restraints were removed before the jury was returned to the courtroom.Â  
Throughout sentencing, the court offered to allow Roberts to come back into the courtroom if he could do so without being disruptive; however, Roberts indicated he would rather remain in the back room.Â  Roberts ultimately returned to the courtroom to make a closing statement to the jury.Â  After deliberations, the jury found the existence of the two aggravating circumstances and recommended a sentence of death.Â Â  Roberts appeals.
ISSUE
Did the trial court commit reversible error in refusing Robertsâ€™ request to be completely absent from sentencing?Â  
DISCUSSION
It is well-established that an accused may waive the right to counsel and proceed pro se.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998), citing Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975).Â  Although a defendantâ€™s decision to proceed pro se may be to his own detriment, it â€œmust be honored out of that respect for the individual which is the lifeblood of the law.â€Â  Id.Â  
Citing State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711 (1987), Roberts asserts a defendant need not be present at all times during a capital trial.Â  We find Bell inapplicable to the facts of this case.Â  There, the defendant twice disrupted the guilt-phase closing argument of his defense counsel, objecting to the trial proceeding on the Sabbath.Â  After being warned against such conduct, Bell again disrupted the proceedings, and was removed to a holding cell without the benefit of any audio hookup.Â  This Court held that the right to be present at trial could be waived, and that Bellâ€™s disruptive conduct amounted to a waiver of the right to be present at trial, such that he could not be heard to complain.Â  
Although it may, under certain circumstances, be permissible to allow a capital defendant to be absent from trial, this does not mean there is a constitutional right to be absent.Â  On the contrary, this Court has specifically held there is no constitutional right of a defendant not to be present at trial.Â  State v. Moore, 308 S.C. 349. 417 S.E.2d 869 (1992).[1] Â Â Accordingly, no constitutional right of Roberts was violated by his continued presence at trial.[2]Â  Â Â Â 
Moreover, Roberts has demonstrated no prejudice from his continued attendance at trial; there is simply no basis to conclude that his death sentence resulted from his presence in a holding cell at the back of the courtroom.Â  Accord State v. Kelly, 331 S.C. 132, 502 S.E.2d 99 (1998), cert. denied, 525 U.S. 1077, 119 S.Ct. 816, 142 L.Ed.2d 675 (1999) (death penalty defendant failed to show prejudice from presence in jury room of religious pamphlet concerning Godâ€™s view of death penalty, where misconduct did not affect juryâ€™s verdict).Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Robertsâ€™ convictions and sentence are affirmed.Â  We have conducted the mandatory review required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â  16-3-25 (1985).Â  The evidence indicates the sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor, the evidence supports the finding of the aggravating circumstances, and the sentence is not disproportionate to that imposed in similar cases.Â  State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883 (2005), cert. denied, ___ U.S.___ 2006 WL 565552 (May 15, 2006); State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999), cert. denied, 529 U.S. 1025 (2000); State v. Johnson, 306 S.C. 119, 410 S.E.2d 547 (1991), cert. denied, 503 U.S. 993 (1992); State v. South, 285 S.C. 529, 331 S.E.2d 775, cert. denied 474 U.S. 888 (1985). 
 AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The defendant in Moore asserted he had a right not to be present at trial in order to preclude an in-court identification of him by the Stateâ€™s witnesses.Â  However, our holding in Moore unequivocally held there is no constitutional right not to be present at trial.Â  Moore applies not only where the defendant wishes to prevent an identification, but applies with equal force in any case in which the defendant desires to absent himself from trial. 
[2] Â Moreover, Rule 16, SCRCrimP, states that, â€œexcept in cases wherein capital punishment is a permissible sentence, a person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his absence. . . â€Â  In a similar situation, the California Supreme Court recently held a â€œcapital defendant may not voluntarily waive his right to be present during . . . those portions of the trial in which evidence is taken, and . . . may not be removed from the courtroom unless he has been disruptive or threatens to be disruptive.â€Â  People v. Huggins, 41 Cal. Rptr. 3d 593 (2006).Â  Similarly, the Alabama Court of Criminal Appeals has recognized that until 1997 (when Alabama Rules Crim. Proc., Rule 9.1(a), (b)(2) was amended), a defendant charged with a capital offense could not waive his right to be present at any phase of the capital trial.Â  Robitaille v. State, ___So.2d ___, 2005 WL 3118795 (Ala. Crim. App. 2005).Â
