title: Harbor Island Ownersâ€™ Association v. Preferred Island Properties
description: In this default-judgment case, the Court affirmed the entry of default by the master-in-equity.  The Court held that a foreign corporation's registered agent for service of process does not constitute a "person designated by statute to accept service" as contemplated in Rule 6(e), SCRCP; therefore, the defendant is not entitled to five extra days to respond to the summons and complaint.  The Court reversed the order of default judgment with respect to the master's finding that a contractual interest rate of eighteen percent applied to the judgment, because there was no evidence in the record to support the finding.  The Court therefore remanded the case to the master with instruction to apply the judgment rate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Harbor Island Ownersâ€™ Association, Respondent,
v.
Preferred Island Properties, Inc., a North Carolina Corporation,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No.Â  26187
Heard May 24, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Robert V. Mathison, Jr., of Mathison & Mathison, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
James B. Richardson, Jr., of Law Office of James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES: Â This is a default-judgment case.Â  Appellant appeals from an order of the master-in-equity that Appellant was in default, and from an order of default judgment.Â  We certified the case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we now affirm the entry-of-default order, and affirm in part and reverse in part the default-judgment order.
FACTS
Appellant is a North Carolina corporation that owned two parcels of property in the Harbor Island subdivision in Beaufort County, South Carolina.Â  On February 6, 2004, Respondent filed a notice and certificate of lien on the two parcels.[1]Â  Respondent served the notice and certificate by mail on Robert Honeycutt (Honeycutt), Appellantâ€™s principal and manager, at Honeycuttâ€™s North Carolina address.Â  
On March 4, 2004, Respondent filed a summons and complaint seeking foreclosure on the two parcels.[2]Â  According to the complaint, Appellant had failed to pay membership fees owed on the two lots for assessment years 1991-1992 through 2003-2004.Â  The fees were owed pursuant to the Harbor Island Ownersâ€™ Association Covenants.
On March 19, 2004, a process server personally served the summons and complaint on Paul Barber (Barber), the person listed with the Secretary of State as Appellantâ€™s registered agent for service of process.Â  Barber swore in his affidavit that he â€œthrew the papers awayâ€ because he thought he had â€œno business affiliationâ€ with Appellant.Â  He swore that he had â€œhad no knowledge of why or how [he] became named as the agent for service forâ€ Appellant.
On April 22, 2004, Respondent filed an affidavit of default with the clerk of court for Beaufort County.Â  Respondent served the affidavit by mail on both Barber and Honeycutt.
Appellantâ€™s attorney became aware of the complaint and the affidavit of default on April 27.Â  On April 28, Appellant filed an answer to the complaint.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On July 22, 2004, Appellant filed a document entitled Motion to Determine that Default Has Not Been Entered and in the Alternative to Set Aside Entry of Default.Â  After a hearing, the master denied the motion.Â  The master found that Appellant was in default and that Appellant had failed to show good cause to set aside the entry of default.Â  
The master also granted Respondentâ€™s motion for default judgment in the amount of the unpaid membership dues.Â  The master found that Respondent was entitled to pre- and post-judgment interest on each late fee at a rate of eighteen percent per annum, which the master found was a contractual rate established by the association covenants.Â  The master then held that Respondent was entitled to recover its damages through foreclosure on the two parcels, and the master declared that he would hold a public auction.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.     
         Whether the master erred in finding that Appellant was in default.
      
      
        
          
      
      
        II. 
         Whether the master erred in finding that a contractual interest rate of eighteen percent applied.
      
    
  

ANALYSIS
We affirm the entry-of-default order and affirm in part and reverse in part the default-judgment order.Â  The master did not abuse his discretion in finding Appellant in default, but the master did abuse his discretion in holding that a contractual interest rate of eighteen percent applied to the judgment.
I.Â  Entry of Default
â€œThe decision whether to set aside an entry of default or a default judgment lies solely within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  The
trial court's decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of that discretion.Â  An abuse of discretion ... occurs when ... the order was controlled by some error of law or when the order, based upon factual, as distinguished from legal conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Roberson v. S. Finance of S.C., Inc., 365 S.C. 6, 9, 615 S.E.2d 112, 114 (2005) (citations and internal quotation omitted).
Appellant argues that Respondentâ€™s affidavit of default was a nullity because it was filed before the time for Appellant to answer had expired.Â  Respondent filed the affidavit of default thirty-four days after serving the complaint on Barber, Appellantâ€™s registered agent.Â  Appellant notes the rule that generally, â€œ[a] defendant shall serve his answer within 30 days after the service of the complaint upon him.â€ Â Rule 12(a), SCRCP.Â  According to Appellant, however, under Rule 6(e), SCRCP, a defendant has thirty-five days to answer if service is made upon a registered agent.
Rule 6(e) provides:

Whenever a party has the right or is required to do some act or take some proceedings within a prescribed Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  period after the service of a notice or other paper upon
him and the notice or paper is served upon him by mail or upon a person designated by statute to accept service,
five days shall be added to the prescribed period. 

Rule 6(e), SCRCP (emphasis added).
In Appellantâ€™s view, a â€œregistered agentâ€ is â€œa person designated by statute to accept service,â€ because a registered agent is a creature of statute.Â  Appellant also points to the South Carolina Reportersâ€™ Comments on various statutes, which seem to view registered agents as statutory agents.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 33-5-101 rptr. cmt. (referring to the registered agent for a domestic corporation as a â€œstatutory agentâ€), 33-5-104 (same, and implicitly differentiating between the Secretary of Stateâ€™s status as a statutory agent and a registered agentâ€™s status as a statutory agent), and 33-15-107 (discussing the â€œappointment of a statutory agentâ€ by a foreign corporation).Â  Because Barber was a statutory agent, Appellant claims, Appellant had thirty-five days within which to file its answer.Â  Because Respondent filed its affidavit of default prior to the expiration of Appellantâ€™s time to file an answer, the affidavit of default was a nullity, and default was never properly entered.
We agree with Respondent that a â€œregistered agentâ€ is not a â€œperson designated by statute to accept serviceâ€ and that Rule 6(e) therefore does not apply.Â  While section 33-15-107 requires a foreign corporation to designate an agent, the statute itself makes no designation.Â  Cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-245 (2005) (providing that service of process is made upon the Secretary of State for businesses that do business in the state without authorization); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-270 (2005) (providing for service of process upon the Director of the Department of Insurance for insurance companies).
Consequently, we affirm the masterâ€™s holding that default was properly entered against Appellant.
II. Â Interest Rate
Concerning the judgment of default, Appellant argues that the master erred in finding that a contractual interest rate of eighteen percent applied to pre- and post-judgment interest on the unpaid membership fees.Â  We agree.
The masterâ€™s findings of fact must be upheld â€œunless wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Roberson, 365 S.C. at 11, 615 S.E.2d at 115.Â  Here, the masterâ€™s finding is not supported by the evidence in the record.
At the damages hearing, Respondent introduced a copy of the neighborhood covenants.Â  Article V, section 6 of the covenants provides that unpaid dues carry â€œinterest thereon at a rate set by the Board of Directors.â€Â  To show the rate set by the board, Respondent called its bookkeeper to testify.Â  Respondentâ€™s attorney asked, â€œAnd what is the interest rate that accrues on those assessments?â€Â  The bookkeeper answered, â€œ18% -- I think, 19%.Â  Itâ€™s in the computer, but I donâ€™t remember it.â€
The master found that the bookkeeperâ€™s testimony supported Respondentâ€™s claim for an eighteen-percent contractual interest rate.Â  We agree with Appellant that the testimony did not constitute evidence supporting the masterâ€™s finding.Â  The bookkeeper did not remember the rate.Â  
Respondent asserts that regardless of the evidence submitted at the hearing, the basis for the masterâ€™s finding, the record reveals an additional sustaining ground.Â  Respondent argues it is entitled to the eighteen-percent rate because the rateâ€™s application was alleged in the complaint.[3]Â  We disagree.Â  
The interest on the unpaid assessments is part of damages.Â  By defaulting, Appellant admitted the allegations in the complaint concerning liability, not damages.Â  Respondent had the burden of proving damages.Â  See Renney v. Dobbs House, Inc., 275 S.C. 562, 566, 274 S.E.2d 290, 292 (1981) (discussing Howard v. Holiday Inns, Inc., 271 S.C. 238, 246 S.E.2d 880 (1978)).Â  
Regarding proof of damages, Rule 55(b)(1), SCRCP, provides:

When the claim of a party seeking judgment by default is for a liquidated amount, a sum certain or
a sum which can by computation be made certain, the judge, upon motion or application of the party
seeking default, and upon affidavit of the amount due, shall enter judgment for that amount and costs
against the party against whom judgment by default is sought, if that party has been defaulted for failure
to appear and if such party is not a minor or incompetent person.Â  A verified pleading may be
used in lieu of an affidavit when the pleading contains information sufficient to determine or
compute the sum certain. 

Here, Respondent attached verified statements of accounts to the complaint. Â See Rule 9(i), SCRCP (providing that â€œ[i]n an action on an account the pleader shall attach a verified copy of the account to the pleading, or if the items of the account are set forth in the pleading, it must be verifiedâ€).Â  These accounts do not reference accrued or accruing interest, let alone a particular interest rate.Â  The account statements, therefore, do not satisfy Rule 55 with respect to the claim for a contractual rate.Â  Further, the complaint itself is not verified; thus, the allegation in the complaint does not satisfy Rule 55, either.Â  
We therefore reverse the masterâ€™s holding that Appellant owes interest on the judgment at a rate of eighteen percent, and we remand the case to the master with instruction to order payment at the judgment rate.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the order denying Appellantâ€™s motion to set aside entry of default.Â  We reverse the finding in the default-judgment order that a contractual interest rate of eighteen percent applied, and remand the case to the master with instruction to apply the judgment rate.
 AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent later filed a lis pendens.
[2] Respondent also pleaded a cause of action for damages, which is not at issue on appeal. Â 
[3] In its complaint, Respondent alleged it was entitled to interest â€œat a rate set by the Board (1 1/2% per month).â€

title: BB&T v. Taylor
description: The Court found Petitioner was not properly served with process and reversed the denial of Petitionerâ€™s motion to set aside a judgment against her.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
BB&T f/k/a Southern National Bank, Respondent,
v.
Carolyn M. Taylor a/k/a Carolyn Yvonne Murphy Taylor,
Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26188Â Â 
Submitted June 21, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Carolyn M. Taylor, of Columbia, Pro Se Petitioner.
John William Ray, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in BB&T v. Taylor, Op. No. 2004-UP-513 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Oct. 14, 2004).Â  Carolyn M. Taylor a/k/a Carolyn Yvonne Murphy Taylor (Petitioner) contends the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the lower courtâ€™s denial of a motion to set aside a judgment against her and in favor of BB&T f/k/a Southern National Bank (Respondent).Â  We find Petitioner was not properly served with process and reverse.Â  
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On May 29, 1998, Respondent filed an action against Petitioner for collection of a consumer debt.Â  Respondent hired a private process server, Robert Jones, who verified Petitionerâ€™s residential address.Â  Jones also obtained the make and model of Petitionerâ€™s vehicle and license tag number through public records.Â  
Jones made nine visits to Petitionerâ€™s residence attempting to serve her, and he left a message on the residenceâ€™s answering machine.Â  On June 17, 1998, Jones arrived at Petitionerâ€™s residence about 4:30 p.m. and departed about 17 minutes later.Â  There were two vehicles in the driveway including the one registered to Petitioner.Â  Jones claimed someone was inside the residence but would not open the door or communicate with him.Â  He called out his intent to leave the papers and then posted the summons and complaint on the front door of the residence.Â  
Respondent filed an affidavit of default, and on August 3, 1998, a judgment in default was entered against Petitioner.Â  On July 16, 2002, Petitioner filed a motion to set aside the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP.Â  Petitioner alleged the default judgment should be set aside because the court lacked personal jurisdiction due to insufficient service of process. The lower court found Petitioner had been sufficiently served with process and denied Petitionerâ€™s motion.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed. Â BB&T v. Taylor, Op. No. 2004-UP-513 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Oct. 14, 2004).Â Â  
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the lower courtâ€™s denial
of Petitionerâ€™s motion to set aside a judgment against her?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.Â  Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 494, 413 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1992).Â  Our standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining whether there was an abuse of discretion.Â  An abuse of discretion arises where the judge issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or where the order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.Â  Tri-County Ice & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
Petitioner alleges she did not personally receive the summons and complaint in this case as required by Rule 4, SCRCP.Â  She contends the Court of Appeals therefore erred in affirming the lower courtâ€™s denial of her motion to set aside a judgment against her.Â  We agree.
Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP, provides:Â  â€œOn motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party . . . from a final judgment, order, or proceeding [because] . . . the judgment is void.â€Â  A judgment is void if a court acts without personal jurisdiction. Â Thomas & Howard Co. v. T.W. Graham & Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995).Â  A court generally obtains personal jurisdiction by the service of a summons.Â  Ex parte S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 350 S.C. 404, 407, 566 S.E.2d 196, 198 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing State v. Sanders, 118 S.C. 498, 502, 110 S.E. 808, 810 (1920) (â€œThe purpose of the summons is to acquire jurisdiction of the person of the defendant. . . .â€)).
Under Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP, service shall be made as follows:

Upon an individual other than a minor under the age of 14 years
or an incompetent person, by delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to him personally or by leaving copies thereof at
his dwelling house or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing therein, or by delivering
a copy to an agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process. 

â€œRule 4, SCRCP, serves at least two purposes.Â  It confers personal jurisdiction on the court and assures the defendant of reasonable notice of the action.â€Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 209, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  
The movant in a Rule 60(b) motion has the burden of presenting evidence proving the facts essential to entitle her to relief.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 304 S.C. 65, 67, 403 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Exacting compliance with the rules is not required to effect service of process.Â  Roche, 318 S.C. at 209-10, 456 S.E.2d at 899.Â  â€œRather, [the Court must] inquire whether the plaintiff has sufficiently complied with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction of the defendant and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.â€Â  Id. at 210, 456 S.E.2d at 899.Â  A presumption of proper service exists when the rules governing service are followed.Â  Roche, 318 S.C. at 211, 456 S.E.2d at 900 (citation omitted). 
The dispositive issue in this case is what constitutes delivery of a copy of
the summons and complaint to the individual personally where the process server has repeatedly attempted to serve process and during the attempt at issue believed an individual was inside the residence but never saw or communicated with the individual.[1]Â  Petitionerâ€™s residence and the manner of service of process are undisputed.Â  In an affidavit of service, Jones stated he posted the documents on the front door â€œafter person(s) inside refused to answer door.â€Â  In a subsequent affidavit, Jones stated he posted the documents on the front door after determining a person was present inside the residence, knocking and calling out to the alleged occupant, determining the alleged occupant would not communicate with him, confirming one of the vehicles at the residence belonged to Petitioner, and calling out his intent to leave the papers.Â  
Although there is no South Carolina case directly on point, we find Patel v. Southern Brokers, Ltd., 277 S.C. 490, 289 S.E.2d 642 (1982), instructive.Â  In Patel, the plaintiff attempted service of process under the long arm statute because the defendant was a North Carolina corporation.Â  The summons and complaint were sent to the defendant by certified mail, return receipt requested.Â  The plaintiff could not enter proof of service because the postal service returned the unopened envelope as refused.Â  Noting â€œtechnical objections to service of processâ€ had been overruled â€œwhere the defendant had not been denied due process,â€ the Court found a defendant could not avoid process by refusing to accept registered mail known to contain a summons and complaint.Â  Id. at 494, 289 S.E.2d at 645. Â Once the documents were made available to the defendant, â€œthe mailman was not required to ram them down the Defendantâ€™s throat.â€Â  Id. at 495, 289 S.E.2d at 645.Â  The Court concluded the defendant had been served with process and the lower court had jurisdiction over the defendant. 
The Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in this case cited foreign authority which dealt with situations in which the process server left the summons and complaint on the door or doorstep of the defendantâ€™s residence after the process server talked to or had contact with an individual inside the residence who refused service.Â  See Taylor, Op. No. 2004-UP-513 (citing Jacobson v. Garland, 487 S.E.2d 640 (Ga. Ct. App. 1997) (sufficient service of process found where process server told defendantâ€™s wife in a face-to-face encounter that he was serving process on her, defendantâ€™s wife closed the door without accepting the documents, and thereafter, process server left documents at the foot of the door and loudly announced he was leaving the documents); Bossuk v. Steinberg, 447 N.E.2d 56 (N.Y. 1983) (sufficient delivery found where the process server announced intention to leave the summons and complaint and left a copy of the documents outside the defendantâ€™s door after a person of suitable age and discretion refused to open the door to accept service); Wood v. Weenig, 736 P.2d 1053 (Utah Ct. App. 1987) (defendant was properly served when process server left summons and complaint on defendantâ€™s doorstep after an individual claiming to be defendantâ€™s daughter and over 14 years old refused to accept documents); CRB v. State, Depâ€™t of Family Servs., 974 P.2d 931 (Wyo. 1999) (sufficient service of process found where after defendant refused to open the door, process server left the summons and complaint in defendantâ€™s mailbox and informed defendant he was being served)).Â  
Unlike the foreign authority cited by the Court of Appeals, Jones merely speculated that an individual of suitable age and discretion was inside Petitionerâ€™s residence and was refusing to communicate with him during his attempts to serve process.Â  Also, Petitioner did not refuse to accept a copy of the summons and complaint, unlike the defendant in Patel.Â  Rather, there are no facts in the record to indicate Petitioner was even aware of the process server and his attempts to serve her.Â  Petitioner was not properly served under these facts because Jones never saw or spoke to anyone who resided in Petitionerâ€™s residence nor did anyone refuse acceptance before Jones attached the summons and complaint to Petitionerâ€™s front door.Â  See generally Willoughby v. Seese Realty Inc., 421 So.2d 691 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1982) (statutory requirements for personal service were not met where the sheriff did not deliver the summons and complaint to the defendant but left a copy of the documents at the defendantâ€™s door); Thomas v. Johnson, 423 S.E.2d 306 (Ga. Ct. App. 1992) (statutory requirements for personal service were not met where process server tacked the summons and complaint to the defendantâ€™s front door and process server never saw or talked to the defendant nor were there any facts to indicate the defendant was aware of the process server).Â  
The process server is not required to ram the documents down a defendantâ€™s throat and personal service of process â€œshould not become a game of wiles and tricks.â€ 62B Am.Jur.2d Process Â§ 190 (2005).Â  However, there must be something more than a mere suspicion of a defendantâ€™s refusal to accept the summons and complaint before we are willing to find a defendant was sufficiently served with process by a means other than strict compliance with Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP.[2] Â Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We find the lower court abused its discretion in denying Petitionerâ€™s motion to set aside the judgment, and we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We remand for proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion. 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Respondent contends we should apply the following factors to determine whether Petitionerâ€™s motion to set aside the judgment was properly granted: the promptness
with which relief is sought, the reasons for the failure to act promptly, the existence of a meritorious defense, and the prejudice to the other parties are relevant.Â  These factors do not apply to a motion made pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP.Â  See New Hampshire Ins. Co. v. Bey Corp., 312 S.C. 47, 50, 435 S.E.2d 377, 379 (Ct. App. 1993) (listing the factors); see, e.g., Hill v. Dotts, 345 S.C. 304, 547 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 2001) (applying the factors to a motion made under Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP); Mictronics, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 548 S.E.2d 223 (Ct. App. 2001) (same).
[2]Â  We find it unnecessary to address Petitionerâ€™s argument regarding Rule 4(g), SCRCP. See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issues is dispositive).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Susie Cornelius, individually, and on behalf of all others similarly situated,
Respondent,
v.
Oconee County, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Oconee County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26189
Heard June 6, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bradley A. Norton and Julie Elisabeth Mahon, both of Norton, Ballenger and Mahon, of Walhalla, and Matlock Elliott and Joshua Howard, both of Haynsworth, Sinkler and Boyd, of Greenville, for Appellant.
James G. Carpenter and Jennifer J. Miller, both of Carpenter Law Firm, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE HILL:Â  In 1976, Oconee County electors approved a referendum authorizing the County to own and operate a wastewater treatment facility, but limiting funding for this service to three sources and limiting service to â€œportions of Oconee County.â€Â  Oconee County appeals a circuit court order holding that these restrictions apply to any expansion of Countyâ€™s sewer system, and awarding respondent Cornelius attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (2005).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The 1976 referendum (Referendum) authorized Oconee County â€œto acquire, purchase, construct and operate a wastewater treatment facility to serve portions of Oconee County, consisting of a treatment plant, trunk lines, connector lines and other necessary and appropriate apparatus.Â  Provided and upon condition that the sole funds utilized for the acquisition, purchase, construction, maintenance and operation of such facilities shall be obtained and derived from: (1) Grants from Federal and State agencies; (2) Revenue earned and derived from the operation of the facilities to be constructed and paid only by the users thereof; and (3) Bonds payable from revenues produced and earned from the operation of such facilities.â€ (emphasis added). Â Pursuant to the Referendum, County built and operates a sewer system serving parts of the County.
In December 2004, respondent Cornelius, a County citizen and taxpayer, brought this declaratory judgment action against County.Â  Cornelius asserted County had adopted and intended to implement a Master Plan that, among other things, anticipated construction of new wastewater treatment facilities.Â  She alleged that County had approved a contract with SCDOT to construct a treatment facility to serve an interstate highway â€œWelcome Center,â€ and that the contract included a cap on sewage treatment charges. Â Cornelius claimed County intended to fund these projects and to offset any losses using ad valorem tax dollars, and contended that this funding scheme violated the conditions set by the 1976 Referendum.[1]Â  County acknowledged its plans to fund sewer expansion using tax monies.
The circuit court granted Cornelius summary judgment, holding that County may fund sewer projects only within its boundaries, and only using the three types of funding listed in the Referendum.Â  The circuit court subsequently awarded Cornelius $9,450 in attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to Â§ 15-77-300.Â  County appeals both orders.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1)
        Whether the circuit court erred in holding County was bound by the terms of the Referendum.
      
      
        
         
      
      
        2)  
         Whether the circuit court abused its discretion in awarding Cornelius attorneysâ€™ fees.
      
    
  

  ANALYSIS
A.     Referendum
The South Carolina Constitution of 1895 placed control of local government affairs largely with the General Assembly.Â  Most notably, Article X, Â§6 of the 1895 Constitution allowed the General Assembly to grant counties the power to levy taxes only for specific listed purposes such as roads, prisons, education, courts, salaries of county officials, and other â€œordinary county purposes.â€Â  The intent of this provision was to â€œhalt county and township taxing and spending except that which was unequivocally for traditional local government purposes.â€Â  Underwood, The Constitution of South Carolina: Vol. II: The Journey Toward Local Self-Government at 83 (1989).Â  As a result, this Court strictly interpreted what constituted an â€œordinary county purposeâ€ for which state government could lawfully permit Â counties to levy taxes or issue bonds. See, e.g., Leonard v. Talbert, 225 S.C. 559, 83 S.E.2d 201 (1954) (act creating physical education commission and providing funding for sports fields for Richland County schools had neither educational nor â€œordinary county purposeâ€ within the meaning of Article X, Â§6).Â  In the same vein, because modern waste treatment practices were not known in 1895 and could not therefore have been an â€œordinaryâ€ county purpose, the Court construed Article X, Â§6 as prohibiting counties from expending tax revenues or bond funds to construct or operate sewerage systems.Â  Doran v. Robertson, 203 S.C. 434, 27 S.E.2d 714 (1943).Â  In 1973, the Constitution was amended and Article VIII, Â§ 16 was added as part of the quest for Home Rule. This Constitutional provision permits a county, upon majority vote of its electors, â€œto acquire by initial construction or purchaseâ€ and to â€œoperateâ€¦sewer systemsâ€¦.â€Â  As noted in Knight v. Salisbury, 262 S.C. 565, 574,Â  206 S.E.2d 875, 879 (1974), the provision removed the obstacles presented by Article X, Â§6 and Doran and â€œexpressly empowers counties to actâ€ in establishing sewer systems.Â  
Oconee County maintains that the purpose of Article VIII, Â§ 16 is to allow voters to decide whether a county should be permitted to initially engage in wastewater treatment functions.Â  County argues that since the Constitution refers to â€œinitial construction or purchase,â€ and since the Referendum referred only to â€œa wastewater treatment facility,â€ the Referendum only limits the funding sources County could use to construct the first facility and does not hinder County from using tax monies or other forms of financing to fund subsequent expansions of the facility or additional sewer system projects.Â  According to County, once the 1976 Referendum passed, County was free to expand its sewer system and service, and to fund that expansion in any way it chose.Â  We disagree. 
As a general rule, once voters have approved a Referendum, a county may expand its sewerage system without further authorization from the electors.Â  See Johnson v. Piedmont Mun. Power Agency, 277 S.C. 345, 287 S.E.2d 476 (1982).Â  The question remains, however, whether such an expansion is subject to the express terms and limitations of the Referendum. 
We hold that a county seeking to expand a utility cannot ignore the express terms of the Article VIII, Â§ 16 referendum that initially authorized the county to own and operate the utility.Â  As Justice Littlejohn observed in Johnson:

The people, speaking through a constitution, endeavor to protect their life, liberty and property by prescribing and limiting the powers of the government.Â  This acts as a bulwark of liberty for the protection of private rights.Â  The Constitution is the instrument of the people to protect themselves against the rule of man as contrasted with the rule of law.
The power of government to demand money from its people by way of taxation, or otherwise, is equivalent to the power to destroy.Â  
277 S.C. at 356, 287 S.E.2d at 482 (Littlejohn, A.J., dissenting).

The Constitution forbids a county from owning and operating a sewer system unless county electors have approved the countyâ€™s assumption of this function by referendum.Â  While nothing in Article VIII, Â§16 requires that the referendum be phrased to restrict the sources of funding a county may use for a sewer system, here Oconee County chose to include such a restriction in the referendum it presented to the voters.Â  Accordingly, the voters of Oconee County approved the referendum, but only on the condition that specific, non-tax based financing be used to construct, operate, and maintain the sewer system. Â To now permit the County to use the fact of a favorable vote as a license to ignore the express terms of that referendum and deploy its general taxing power to finance expansion of the system would subvert the popular will and deprive â€œthe people [of the right] to protect themselves against the rule of manâ€¦.â€Â  
County alternatively contends that a constitutional referendum is merely one of several methods by which a county may be authorized to provide sewer services.Â  County claims S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-55-1410(A) (2002) provides an independent basis upon which a county may opt to provide sewer services using ad valorem tax funds.Â  We disagree.Â  This statute was enacted in 1975 pursuant to the Constitutionâ€™s directive to the General Assembly to implement Home Rule, see Hospitality Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. County of Charleston, 320 S.C. 219, 464 S.E.2d 113 (1995), Â and provides the governmental framework for a county to operate a sewer system that has been initially authorized by constitutional referendum.Â  Cf. Murphree v. Mottel, 267 S.C. 80, 226 S.E.2d 36 (1976) (favorable Article VIII, Â§ 16 referendum is prerequisite for county operation of water or sewer facilities).Â  The statute does not permit a county to operate wastewater treatment facilities in the absence of a constitutional referendum.[2]
County next contends that it can enlarge its sewer system utilizing ad valorem tax monies, citing S.C. Const. art. VIII, Â§ 7, which states, â€œThe General Assembly shall provide by general law forâ€¦powersâ€¦of counties, including the power to taxâ€¦.â€Â  This general taxing provision does not prevail over the specific requirement of the constitutional referendum mandated by Â Article VIII, Â§ 16.Â  See Â S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 23 (â€œThe provisions of the Constitution shall be taken, deemed, and construed to be mandatory and prohibitory, and not merely directoryâ€¦â€). 
Finally, County points to its general authority to expend tax revenues in aid of economic development, including sewer services, as a separate basis upon which it may expand sewer services independent of the Referendum.Â  We disagree.Â  A countyâ€™s general taxing authority does not trump the constitutional requirement that electors approve the operation of sewer services by referendum. Cf. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992) (general constitutional provision does not overrule specific constitutional clause). 
We therefore affirm the circuit court order holding that County is bound by the terms of the Referendum both geographically[3] and financially in expanding its wastewater treatment services and facilities.Â  
B.      Attorneysâ€™ Fees
Cornelius was awarded $9,450 attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (2005).Â  County argues it acted with â€œsubstantial justificationâ€ because there are no preexisting judicial precedents on these issues, merely attorney general opinions, and that Cornelius was not a â€œprevailing partyâ€ in that this was merely a declaratory judgment action to define rights, duties, and obligations, and that therefore the fee award was improper.Â  We affirm the award.
In order to make an award under Â§ 15-77-300, the trial court must find: 1) the party seeking the award was the prevailing party; 2) the state agency Â acted without substantial justification; and 3) that no special circumstances make an award unjust. Jasper County Bd. of Educ. v. Jasper County Grand Jury, 303 S.C. 49, 398 S.E.2d 498 (1990).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to award or deny fees under Â§ 15-77-300 will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.  
Taking Countyâ€™s arguments in reverse order, this Court has never held that Â§ 15-77-300 is inapplicable to declaratory judgment actions.Â  In fact, the Court has decided numerous declaratory judgment appeals where fees were sought pursuant to the statute.Â  See, e.g., City of Charleston v. Masi, 362 S.C. 505, 609 S.E.2d 301 (2005) (no prevailing party under statute where declaratory judgment action dismissed as moot); Eargle v. Horry County, 344 S.C. 449, 545 S.E.2d 276 (2001) (remanding declaratory judgment action for determination of statutory award); S.C. Tax Commâ€™n v. United Oil Marketers, Inc., 306 S.C. 384, 412 S.E.2d 402 (1991) (no abuse of discretion in denying award to non-prevailing party in declaratory judgment action).Â  While the statute specifically exempts certain types of suits, declaratory judgments are not among them.Â  A party whose position prevails in a declaratory judgment dispute with a state agency may be awarded fees under Â§ 15-77-300.
The trial court can award attorneysâ€™ fees under the statute only if it finds the State â€œagency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claimâ€¦.â€Â  Â§ 15-77-300(1).Â  An agency acts with â€œsubstantial justificationâ€ within the meaning of the statute when its position has a â€œreasonable basis in law and fact.â€ McDowell v. SCDSS, 304 S.C. 539, 542, 405 S.E.2d 830, 832 (1991).Â  Contrary to Countyâ€™s contention, the fact that novel issues were raised does not mean County was substantially justified in opposing Cornelius.Â  Declaratory judgment actions by their very nature often present novel questions.Â  See, e.g. Eargle, supra (authority of county administrator to suspend elected officialâ€™s employees); United Oil Marketers, supra (constitutionality of license tax incentive statute for gas/ethanol blend); Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 394 S.E.2d 709 (1990) (to define relationship between sheriffâ€™s office and county council).Â  Moreover, County cited no viable authority supporting its position that it was no longer bound by the Referendumâ€™s terms.Â  We agree with the circuit court that County acted without substantial justification, and no special circumstances render the attorneysâ€™ fee award unjust.
We find the circuit court properly exercised its discretion in awarding Cornelius fees under Â§ 15-77-300.Â  Jasper County, supra.
CONCLUSION
The circuit court orders holding County is bound by the terms of the Referendum and awarding Cornelius attorneysâ€™ fees are
 AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] Cornelius also contended that County intended to fund water projects.Â  The circuit court held County lacked authority to build or operate a water system, a holding not challenged on appeal.
[2] Indeed, the last sentence of section 44-55-1410(A) plainly provides that â€œ[n]othing herein contained is intended to authorize the levy of taxes.â€ 
[3] Nothing in the Referendum or the circuit court order, however, limits Countyâ€™s authority to contract with other public or private entities to provide sewer services. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§44-55-1410(D); Â§ 6-15-20.

v.

Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., Mildred Russell Williams Nieman, John R. Russell, Thaddeus Russell Williams, Virginia Carol Williams, and Cecilia Frances Williams, Appellants.

v.

  
    
      
        Wachovia Bank, N.A., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, Sr., Virginia C. Williams, T. Russell Williams, Cecilia F. Williams, Virginia U. Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., W. Scott Russell, and John R. Russell, Defendants,
        of which Wachovia Bank, N.A., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, Sr., Virginia C. Williams, T. Russell Williams, Cecilia F. Williams, Virginia U. Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., and John R. Russell are Respondents-Appellants
        and W. Scott Russell is Respondent.

v.

  
    
      
        Wachovia Bank, N.A., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, Sr., Virginia C. Williams, T. Russell Williams, Cecilia F. Williams, Virginia U. Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., W. Scott Russell, and John R. Russell, Defendants,
        of which Wachovia Bank, N.A., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, Sr., Virginia C. Williams, T. Russell Williams, Cecilia F. Williams, Virginia U. Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., and John R. Russell are Appellants-Respondents
        and W. Scott Russell is Respondent.
      
    
  

AND

  
    
      
        In the Matter of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, Deceased,--- Walker Scott Russell, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Virginia U. Russell, Donald S. Russell, Jr., Mildred Russell Williams Neiman, John R. Russell, and Wachovia Bank, N.A. as Personal Representative, Appellants.
      
    
  

AND

  
    
      
        Wachovia Bank, N.A., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Donald S. Russell, deceased, Third-Party Appellant-  Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Virginia Williams, Russell Williams, Cecilia Williams, Walker Scott Russell, Jr., and Grace Johnson Russell, Third-Party Respondents,
        Of which Virginia Williams, Russell Williams and Cecilia Williams are Third-Party Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County

Opinion No. 26190
Heard April 6, 2005 - Filed July 24, 2006Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Stanley T. Case and Edward G. Smith, of Butler Means Evins & Browne, of Spartanburg, for Appellant-Respondent Wachovia Bank.
        G. Dewey Oxner, Jr., and Moffatt G. McDonald, of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent Estate of Virginia U. Russell.
        R. Ray Dennis, of Dennis Shaw & Drennan, of Spartanburg, for Appellants-Respondents John R. Russell and Donald S. Russell, Jr.
        Thomas E. McCutchen and Hoover C. Blanton, of McCutchen Blanton Johnson & Barnette, of Columbia, for Appellants Virginia C. Williams, T. Russell Williams, and Cecelia F. Williams.Â  
        Desa A. Ballard and Jason B. Buffkin, of Law Offices of Desa Ballard, of West Columbia; and Joseph M. McCulloch, Jr., of Law Offices of Joe McCulloch, of Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant Mildred R. Neiman.
        J. Neil Robinson, of Robinson Law Office, of Charlotte; and Leo A. Dryer, Jr., of Dryer Law Offices, of Columbia, for Respondent Walker Scott Russell.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Â Â  The underlying litigation began when beneficiaries of an estate challenged the validity of a will and two trusts, alleging the documents were procured by undue influence.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.Â  This Court affirmed as modified.Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, 353 S.C. 208, 578 S.E.2d 329 (2003).Â  After remittitur was issued, certain defendants moved for summary judgment, seeking to enforce no-contest clauses appearing in the will and revocable trust.Â  The trial court denied summary judgment, ruling that the no-contest clauses were unenforceable because beneficiaries had probable cause to challenge the estate plan.Â  The court also issued two orders regarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  After certifying this case for review pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we affirm in part and reverse in part. 
Factual/Procedural Background
Mildred Russell Neiman (Mim) and Walker Scott Russell (Scott) each filed actions to set aside the will, and revocable and irrevocable trusts of their father, Donald Stuart Russell (Testator).[1]Â  In general, the complaints alleged that Testator was unduly influenced and coerced by Mimâ€™s children (the Williams Children), and perhaps others, to design his estate plan as he did.Â  Named defendants included the following:Â  the Williams Children; Mimâ€™s ex-husband (Thad Williams); Wachovia Bank (Wachovia), the executor of the estate and the trustee; Testatorâ€™s wife, Virginia U. Russell (Mrs. Russell), who is now deceased; and Testatorâ€™s two other children, John R. Russell (Johnny) and Donald R. Russell, Jr. (Donnie).
After extensive discovery was conducted, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.Â  This Court affirmed as modified, holding that the will and trusts were not procured by undue influence.Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, 353 S.C. 208, 578 S.E.2d 329 (2003). Â As to the will contest, we found that the record was â€œdevoid of any evidence that the Williams Children or Thad influenced the execution or any modification of the will.â€Â  Id. at 219, 578 S.E.2d at 335.Â  Similarly, as to the trust contest, we found that there was â€œno evidence to make out a prima facie case of undue influence . . . .â€ Id. at 224, 578 S.E.2d at 337.Â Â Â Â Â  
Following remittitur, the Williams Children filed a motion for summary judgment seeking to enforce the no-contest clauses appearing in Testatorâ€™s will and revocable trust.Â  Wachovia intervened, making similar arguments. Â Â The no-contest clauses provided that beneficiaries who challenged the validity of the will and trust documents would be disinherited.Â  Therefore, if enforced, these provisions would have the effect of disinheriting Mim and Scott for bringing the underlying actions.Â  
Following a hearing, the trial court issued three orders that are the subject of the present appeal.Â  In the first order, the trial court found that Scott and Mim had probable cause to believe that Testator had been unduly influenced by the Williams Children, and perhaps others, prior to his death.Â  As a result, the court ruled that the no-contest clauses were invalid and unenforceable.Â  Wachovia, Mrs. Russellâ€™s estate, Donnie, and Johnny appeal.Â Â Â  
In the second order, the trial court ordered Mim to pay attorneyâ€™s fees and costs incurred by Wachovia in the amount of $264,995.31, by her motherâ€™s estate in the amount of $147,110.25,[2] and by her brothers, Johnny and Donnie, in the amount of $97,412.83.Â  Mim appeals.Â  
Finally, in the third order, the trial court denied a motion for sanctions filed against Scott and his attorneys.Â  The court also denied the Williams Childrenâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. Â The Williams Children appeal. 
Accordingly, the issues presented on appeal are as follows:

  
    I.
    Did the trial court properly grant summary judgment in favor of Mim and Scott, finding they had probable cause to contest the validity of the estate plan?
  
  
    II.       
    Did the trial court properly order Mim to pay certain attorney’s fees and costs?
  
  
    III.        
    Did the trial court properly deny the Williams Children’s request for attorney’s fees and costs?
  

Law/Analysis
I.Â  No-Contest Clauses
Wachovia, Mrs. Russellâ€™s estate, Donnie, and Johnny contend that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Mim and Scott, finding they had probable cause to contest the validity of the estate plan. Â We agree.
In general, clauses in a will designed to penalize beneficiaries for contesting a will or instituting other proceedings relating to the estate are valid and enforceable.Â  E.g., Cox v. Fowler, 614 S.E.2d 59 (Ga. 2005); In re Estate of Mumby, 982 P.2d 1219, 1224 (Wash. Ct. App. 1999).Â  Commonly referred to as â€œno-contestâ€ or â€œin terroremâ€[3] clauses, such clauses may â€œprotect estates from costly and time-consuming litigationâ€ and â€œminimize the bickering over the competence and capacity of testators, and the various amounts bequeathed.â€Â  In re Estate of Seymour, 600 P.2d 274, 278 (N.M. 1979).Â  No-contest clauses may have the desirable effect of ensuring that the details of a testatorâ€™s private life are not made public.Â  Cf. Smithsonian Instit. v. Meach, 169 U.S. 398, 402-03 (1898) (stating that will contests frequently bring â€œto light matters of private life that ought never to be made publicâ€).Â Â  
But courts in South Carolina and North Carolina,[4] along with a majority of jurisdictions, have recognized an exception to the general rule that no-contest clauses are valid and enforceable.Â  Under South Carolina law, a no-contest clause is unenforceable if the challenger has probable cause for instituting proceedings.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-905 (1986).Â  Similarly, North Carolina law provides that a no-contest clause is unenforceable against a person who in good faith and with probable cause challenges the validity of a will.Â  Ryan v. Wachovia Bank & Trust Co., 70 S.E.2d 853, 856 (N.C. 1952).Â  
In the South Carolina case of Rouse v. Branch, the Court held that beneficiaries contesting a will on the ground that the will was a forgery did not forfeit their right to inherit.Â  91 S.C. at 118, 74 S.E. at 135.Â  In so holding, the Court explained: 

  The right of a contestant to institute judicial proceedings upon probable cause, to ascertain whether the will was ever executed by the apparent testator, is founded upon justice and morality.Â  If a devisee should accept the fruits of the crime of forgery, under the belief, and upon probable cause, that it was a forgery he would thereby become morally a particeps criminis; and yet if he is unwilling to commit this moral crime, he is confronted with the alternative of doing so, or of taking the risk of losing all, under the will, in case it should be found not to be a forgery.Â  
  Public policy forbids that he should be tempted in such a manner.

Id.Â  Accordingly, if a beneficiary has a belief, based on probable cause, that a will constitutes a forgery, the beneficiary may (and should) contest the validity of the will, without fear of being disinherited under the terms of a no-contest clause. 
Likewise, beneficiaries are permitted to make bona fide inquiries into whether a will was procured through undue influence or duress. Â In the North Carolina case of Ryan v. Wachovia Bank & Trust Co., six of testatorâ€™s ten children contested the will, alleging that testatorâ€™s signature was obtained through undue influence and duress, and that testator was not even capable of executing the document.Â  70 S.E.2d at 853.Â  Testator was ninety-years old when he died; he was worn out and feeble; was unable to work for several years prior to his death; and, at times, did not recognize his children.Â  Id. at 854.Â  Evidence was also submitted that for several years prior to testatorâ€™s death, two of his daughtersâ€”who were among the chief beneficiaries under the willâ€”were always present when testatorâ€™s other children visited him.Â  Based on this evidence, the court held that a subsequent action challenging the validity of the will was brought in good faith and based on probable cause.Â  Accordingly, the no-contest clause was unenforceable against the challenger.Â  Id.
In so holding, the court explained: 

  In our opinion, a bona fide inquiry whether a will was procured through fraud or undue influence, should not be stifled by any prohibition contained in the instrument itself. 
  . . . 
  There is a very great difference between vexatious litigation instituted by a disappointed heir, next of kin, legatee or devisee, without probable cause, and litigation instituted in good faith and with probable cause, which leads the contestant to believe that a purported will is not in fact the will of the purported testator.Â  

Id. at 856-57.Â  
In the present case, Testator amended both his will and revocable trust approximately fifteen months before he died to include provisions disinheriting beneficiaries who contested the validity of his estate plan.Â  Accordingly, the second codicil to the will provides:

  Should any beneficiary of this Will or of the trust agreement . . . contest the validity of this Will or any provision thereof or attempt to prevent any provision from being carried out in accordance with its terms in legal proceedings or otherwise, then any interest provided for such beneficiary and his or her descendents is revoked and such beneficiary shall be deemed to have predeceased me for all purposes under this Will.

Similarly, the revocable trust was amended to provide:

  Should any beneficiary of this trust contest the validity of this trust or any provision thereof or attempt to prevent any provision thereof from being carried out in accordance with its terms in legal proceedings or otherwise, then any interest provided herein for such beneficiary and his or her descendents in this trust is revoked and such beneficiary and his or her descendents shall be deemed to have predeceased me for all purposes under this trust.

Despite the existence of these provisions, two of Testatorâ€™s children, Mim and Scott, each filed lawsuits alleging that the will and trust documents were procured by undue influence.Â  After extensive discovery was conducted, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.Â  This Court affirmed.Â  
After remittitur was issued, defendants moved for summary judgment seeking to enforce the no-contest clauses.Â  After a hearing, the trial judge found that Mim and Scott â€œhad sufficient evidence to support their reasonable beliefâ€ that Testator had been unduly influenced.Â  In support of this ruling, the court cited the strife and discord in the family, particularly between Mim and her children, the Williams Children.Â  The court also noted that Mim and Scott were treated less advantageously under the estate plan than they believed Testator had intended.[5] Â Accordingly, the judge granted summary judgment in favor of Mim and Scott, finding that they had probable cause to challenge the estate plan.Â  As a result, the judge ruled that the no-contest clauses were invalid and unenforceable.Â  
Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material fact such that the moving party must prevail as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  When reviewing a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  The evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 493-94, 567 S.E.2d at 860.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Mim and Scott, we hold that summary judgment was improperly granted.Â  Mim and Scott did not have probable cause to bring the underlying actions.Â  Family discord and strife, coupled with a less-than-favorable inheritance, do not constitute probable cause.Â  Moreover, the fact that Testator did not announce that the Williams Children would share in the estate is not reason to believe he was unduly influenced to favor them.Â  
Any suspicions Mim and Scott may have had about the influence of others over Testator should have been dispelled by the overwhelming evidence of Testatorâ€™s abilities.Â  Unlike the testator in Ryan, Testator maintained his physical and mental health up until his death.Â  He continued to serve as a federal judge, driving himself to and from work.Â  He was fully capable of executing testamentary documents.Â  He maintained his independence, was freely permitted to come and go from his home and office as he desired, having opportunities to visit relatives, friends, and business associates without supervision. 
Therefore, because we find that Mim and Scott lacked probable cause to contest the estate plan, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment.Â  Consequently, we find that the no-contest clauses in both the will and trust are valid and enforceable. To hold otherwise would undermine Testatorâ€™s intent.Â  See Matter of Clark, 308 S.C. 328, 417 S.E.2d 856 (1992) (explaining that the cardinal rule for interpreting and construing a will is the determination of the testatorâ€™s intent).Â  
There is evidence throughout the record that Testator anticipated that certain beneficiaries would contest the validity of his estate plan.Â  He told his attorney and his son, Donnie, that he anticipated a challenge.Â  He asked one of his former law clerks to represent the Williams Children in the event a challenge was brought.Â  He even went so far as to have himself examined by a psychiatrist to create a record of his testamentary capacity.Â  And most importantly, he amended his will and revocable trust to include language explicitly providing that beneficiaries who contested the validity of the estate plan would have their interest revoked and â€œshall be deemed to have predeceased [him].â€[6]Â  In sum, he did all that he could have to ensure that his wishes would be respected.Â  If a no-contest clause cannot be upheld under these facts, such a clause would not ever be enforceable.Â  
Therefore, by giving the no-contest clauses their full, intended effect, we honor Testatorâ€™s wishes.
II.  Sanctions Against Mim
The trial court found that Mim improperly continued the litigation of this case, even after she realized that the facts did not support her claims.Â  Consequently, the court ordered Mim to pay certain attorneyâ€™s fees and costs incurred from the point in the litigation that she should have realized the lawsuit was frivolous.Â  We agree with the imposition of sanctions.[7]
Sanctions were imposed pursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceedings Sanctions Act (FCPSA)[8] and Rule 11 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure (SCRCP).Â  
The FCPSA provides:

  Any person who takes part in the procurement, initiation, continuation, or defense of any civil proceeding is subject to being assessed for payment of all or a portion of the attorneyâ€™s fees and court costs of the other party if:
  (1) he does so primarily for a purpose other than that of securing the proper discovery, joinder of parties, or adjudication of the claim upon which the proceedings are based; and
  (2) the proceedings have terminated in favor of the person seeking an assessment of the fees and costs.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10 (Supp. 2002) (emphasis added).Â  A party continues litigation with a proper purpose if he â€œreasonably believes in the facts upon which his claim is based and . . . relies upon the advice of counsel, sought in good faith and given after full disclosure of all facts within his knowledge . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-20 (Supp. 2002).Â  When reviewing a trial courtâ€™s decision to impose sanctions under the FCPSA, this Court takes its own view of the evidence.Â  Father v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Services, 353 S.C. 254, 260, 578 S.E.2d 11, 14 (2003).
After the complaints in the present case were filed, defendants submitted the following information to the plaintiffs and to the court:Â  (1) an affidavit from Testatorâ€™s attorney, who drafted the will and trust documents; (2) affidavits from Testatorâ€™s colleagues on the Fourth Circuit; (3) an affidavit from one of Testatorâ€™s personal friends, a former Chief Justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court; (4) an affidavit from Testatorâ€™s personal physician; and (5) copies of all of Testatorâ€™s estate documents, dating back until the late 1950s.
The affidavit of Testatorâ€™s attorney established that Testatorâ€™s final will and trust documents reflected Testatorâ€™s desires.Â  The attorney described Testator as â€œcompetent, alert, and capable of making independent decisions.â€Â  The attorney also stated that Testator â€œwas aware of the extent and nature of his property, maintained control over his property and understood in detail his business affairs . . . .â€Â  Affidavits from Testatorâ€™s colleagues and friends confirmed that Testator maintained both his independence and intellect up until his death.Â  Testatorâ€™s physician, who observed Testator six weeks before his death, described Testator as â€œindependent and clear thinking, showing no signs of mental incapacity.â€Â  Moreover, he stated that Testator â€œnever complained . . . that he was mistreated by any personâ€ and never showed signs of physical abuse.Â  Finally, documents produced from Wachoviaâ€™s files revealed that over the course of four decades, Testator had never treated his children equally in his estate plans.
The trial court ruled that, based on this information, Mim should not have continued the litigation.Â  We agree.Â  The affidavit from Testatorâ€™s attorney made it clear that the estate plan represented Testatorâ€™s wishes.Â  Other affidavits confirmed that Testator was fully capable of thinking for himself and executing his testamentary documents as he desired. Â Mimâ€™s argument that she continued the litigation on the advice of counsel is without merit because subsequent discovery revealed that she was not entirely honest with her attorneys.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial court properly imposed sanctions pursuant to the FCPSA.
Mim was also sanctioned pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP, for submitting an affidavit that the trial court later described as â€œfalse.â€Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s assessment of the affidavit and therefore hold that the court properly imposed sanctions pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  Rule 11(a) provides, in part, as follows:

  The signature of an attorney or party [on a pleading, motion, or other paper] constitutes a certificate by him that he has read the pleading, motion or other paper; that to the best of his knowledge, information and belief there is good ground to support it; and that it is not interposed for delay.
  . . .
  If a pleading, motion, or other paper is signed in violation of this Rule, the court, upon motion or upon its own initiative, may impose upon the person who signed it, a represented party, or both, an appropriate sanction, which may include an order to pay to the other party or parties the amount of the reasonable expenses incurred because of the filing of the pleading, motion or other paper, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee. Â 

On appeal, the imposition of sanctions pursuant to this rule will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Runyon v. Wright, 322 S.C. 15, 19, 471 S.E.2d 160, 162 (1996).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion may be found if the conclusions reached by the court are without reasonable factual support.â€Â  Id. 
We hold that the trial court properly awarded sanctions pursuant to Rule 11.Â  Mimâ€™s own deposition testimony directly contradicts statements made in her affidavit.Â  In the affidavit, Mim stated that Testator â€œalways promised and intended to treat his children equally with regards [sic] to his estate.â€Â  She also stated that the Williams Children prevented her from seeing Testator.Â  Finally, she attested that the Williams Children had been violent and abusive toward Testator.
Each of these statements was later contradicted in Mimâ€™s deposition testimony, demonstrating that the affidavit she signed and submitted to the court was not based on knowledge, information, or belief that there were grounds to support it.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in ordering Mim to pay reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs from the time defendantsâ€™ summary judgment motion was first argued, until the time when summary judgment was granted.[9]
Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s imposition of sanctions against Mim.Â  
III.Â  The Williams Children
Like the other defendants, the Williams Children moved for sanctions pursuant to the FCPSA and Rule 11.Â  But the court ruled that the Williams Childrenâ€™s motion was filed too late.Â  We disagree.
Generally, a trial judge loses jurisdiction[10] over a case when the time to file post-trial motions has elapsed.Â  Ex parte Beard, 359 S.C. 351, 358, 597 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An order is not final until it is entered by the clerk of court; and until the order or judgment is entered by the clerk of court, the judge retains control of the case.Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 22, 624 S.E.2d 643, 646 (2006).Â  As a result, a motion for sanctions must be filed within ten days of the notice of entry of judgment.Â  Pitman v. Republic Leasing Co., Inc., 351 S.C. 429, 432, 570 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 2002).[11]Â  
In the present case, the trial judge signed the order granting summary judgment on April 27, 2001.Â  That same day, the trial judge faxed a letter to all attorneys, including the Williams Childrenâ€™s attorneys, notifying them that the order was being filed that day.Â  In addition, the clerk of court file-stamped the judgment sheet on April 27, indicating that the order was filed that day.Â  However, judgment was not entered by the clerk until May 8, 2001.Â  
The Williams Children filed their motion for sanctions on May 14, 2001, which is within the ten day time limit.Â  Therefore, the trial court erred in finding that it lacked jurisdiction to consider the motion.Â  Accordingly, the issue of sanctions pursuant to the FCPSA and Rule 11 should be remanded to the trial court.
Conclusion
Because Mim and Scott did not have probable cause to contest the estate plan, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment in their favor.Â  We also hold that the trial court properly imposed sanctions against Mim.Â  However, we hold that the trial court erred in declining to address the issue of sanctions sought by the Williams Children.Â  Therefore, the issue of sanctions is remanded to the trial court for a decision on its merits.
MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Perry M. Buckner, concur.

[1] Testator served as an active judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit until his death on February 22, 1998, at the age of 92.Â  Prior to his appointment to the federal bench, Testator served as governor of South Carolina, United States senator from South Carolina, and President of the University of South Carolina.Â Â Â Â Â  
[2] This award was later increased to $165,060.68, after the court realized that the original award did not include costs.Â Â Â Â  
[3] â€œTechnically, a no-contest clause is only one type of in terrorem clause, the latter term including any clause seeking to coerce a person into taking or refusing to take some action.â€Â  Martin D. Begleiter, Anti-Contest Clauses:Â  When You Care Enough to Send the Final Threat, 26 Ariz. St. L.J. 629, n. 2 (1994).Â  The terms are typically used interchangeably, but we use the term â€œno-contestâ€ throughout this opinion because the clauses in the present case specifically address the consequences of contesting the estate plan.
[4] In our prior opinion, we held that issues surrounding the will were governed by South Carolina law, and issues surrounding the trust were governed by North Carolina law.Â  Because the no-contest clauses appear in both the will and trust, we analyze this issue under the law of each state.Â  In the end, however, we find that the legal standard is the same under both South and North Carolina law. 
[5] Testatorâ€™s estate totaled approximately $33,000,000.Â  Upon Mrs. Russellâ€™s death, Scott was to receive $750,000 in trust for life.Â  Testatorâ€™s other sons, Donnie and Johnny, were each to receive a one-third share of the remaining balance.Â  Mim, however, was to share the remaining one-third of the balance equally with her children, the Williams Children, in trust for life.Â  The estate plan also directed that upon Mimâ€™s death, funds remaining in her trust would pass to the Williams Children. Â 
[6] Because the no-contest clauses at issue in this case provided that, in the event of a dispute, oneâ€™s interest would be given over to another, the clauses were not merely in terrorem but were also intended to effect a forfeiture.Â  See Mallet v. Smith, 27 S.C. Eq. (3 Rich. Eq.) 12 (1853) (explaining that when a clause merely states that beneficiaries shall not dispute the terms of a will, the clause is considered in terrorem, and forfeiture will not result; but when a clause also provides for the giving over of oneâ€™s interest in the event of a dispute, then a forfeiture will result).
[7] We have held that the litigation was initiated without probable cause.Â  However, we award attorneysâ€™ fees and costs only for the period requested.
[8] We recognize that the General Assembly recently amended or repealed various sections of this Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  Nonetheless, we apply the law as it existed at the time judgment was entered.
[9] Because we hold that Mim (and Scott) lacked probable cause from the outset to bring the underlying actions, we would support an award of reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs spanning the entire litigation of this case.Â  But since we have been asked only whether the trial court properly awarded fees and costs measured from the time summary judgment was first argued until the time it was granted, we affirm the amount awarded, limited as it may be.
[10] Jurisdiction refers to the trial courtâ€™s authority to retain jurisdiction over the case, not the courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See Ex parte Beard, 359 S.C. at 358.Â  (explaining that the ten day rule is a time limitation on the courtâ€™s ability to retain the case not the power of the trial court to hear cases of that nature).
[11] We do distinguish between the FCPSA and the Rule 11 sanctions.Â  There is no requirement that a motion for sanctions made pursuant to Rule 11 be made within ten days from notice of entry of judgment.Â  See Ex parte Beard, 359 S.C. at 359-60, 597 S.E.2d at 839 (holding that a motion for sanctions pursuant to the FCPSA must be filed within ten days of notice of entry of judgment but not a motion under Rule 11).Â  As a result, we decline to address what time limit is proper with regard to the Rule 11 sanctions because the issue is not before us.Â  However, since the motion made pursuant the FCPSA is proper it is only logical that the Rule 11 motion was timely according to Ex parte Beard.Â  See The Father v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 345 S.C. 57, 72, 545 S.E.2d 523, 531 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating that criteria for Rule 11 sanctions are essentially the same as those for sanctions under the FCPSA).Â  Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Kenneth Ray Martin, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26191
Submitted June 26, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Michael J. Virzi, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Jason B. Buffkin, of West Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to reinstatement of the Deferred Disciplinary Agreement under a renewed schedule, an admonition, or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the Agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.

FACTS
Matter I
Since his admission to the practice of law in 1999, respondent has been a sole practitioner.Â  In January 2002, Client A retained respondent to represent her in a claim to recover money and property from a former boyfriend.Â  During the representation, respondent failed to ensure that his office had a system for accurate recordation and retention of incoming telephone messages and he lost documents related to Client Aâ€™s case.Â Â Â  
Respondent admits that, from January through June 2002, his only action on behalf of Client A was the preparation of one demand letter; he concedes, however, that he has no proof that he actually prepared the letter.Â  Respondent further admits he knowingly failed to respond to Client Aâ€™s inquires regarding the status of her case.Â  
In July 2002, respondent sent a letter to Client A informing her that he did not have time to handle her case.Â  He returned all fees paid by Client A and advised her regarding the statute of limitations.Â Â Â Â Â  
During its investigation of this matter, respondent knowingly failed to respond to two separate telephone messages from ODC, but otherwise fully cooperated with ODCâ€™s investigation into this matter.Â  
Matter II
On August 27, 2004, respondent entered into a Deferred Disciplinary Agreement in resolution of the grievance discussed above. Respondent agreed as follows:Â  1) to retain the services of a law office management advisor approved by ODC within fifteen days; 2) to file with ODC an initial report by the advisor within sixty days; and 3) that failure to comply with the terms of the agreement would constitute misconduct.Â  An Investigative Panel of the Commission on Lawyer Conduct accepted the Deferred Disciplinary Agreement and, by letter dated September 30, 2004, ODC notified respondent that the deadlines in the agreement would be measured from September 30, 2004. 
Respondent did not meet the deadlines for hiring a law office management advisor and filing a report with ODC.Â  Respondent states he had spoken with an advisor and that his failure to hire the advisor was due to his inability to pay the fee.Â  Respondent made no attempt to contact ODC to request an extension of time or otherwise discuss the matter until contacted by ODC several months later.Â  
The deferment contained in the Deferred Disciplinary Agreement was subsequently revoked and the grievance reopened.Â  Nevertheless, respondent represents that, on his own initiative, he hired a law office management advisor who completed a review of his office procedures and that he has implemented the advisorâ€™s recommendations.Â Â  
Matter III
In May 2004, respondent was retained by Client B for purposes of a warranty matter.Â  At the time, respondent told Client B he hoped the matter would be resolved in six months.Â  Respondent sent a letter to the defendant in May 2004.Â  
Client B alleges he contacted respondent in October 2004, at which time respondent assured him he would call the following Monday and brief him on the status of the warranty matter.Â  Despite the promise, respondent failed to contact Client B during the remainder of 2004.Â  
On April 12, 2005, Client B contacted respondent.Â  Respondent informed him that his warranty had expired in January 2005 but that respondent had preserved his claim prior to that date.Â  Respondent failed to provide Client B with any documents or other evidence of claim preservation.Â  
Respondent represents Client Bâ€™s claim is preserved and he continues to represent Client B in this matter.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, particularly Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation), Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully fail to comply with the terms of a finally accepted deferred disciplinary agreement).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
