PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to issuance of either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the Agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent practices law primarily in the area of real estate transactions.Â  He also owns a title insurance agency known as Hanover Title Agency, Inc., (Hanover) which is located on the premises of his law office. 
During 2001 and 2002, Hanover was owned by respondent and his then-employee Margaret McNelis.Â  McNelis is not a lawyer.Â  
Since the late 1990s and at respondentâ€™s direction, McNelis regularly closed real estate transactions on respondentâ€™s behalf when he was not present.Â  On at least 49 such occasions between April 2001 and July 2002, respondent was on vacation and not in the office when McNelis closed transactions and signed closing documents on respondentâ€™s behalf.Â  On other occasions, McNelis closed real estate transactions at respondentâ€™s direction because respondent was delayed in returning to the office from other business or the closing occurred at a time other than originally scheduled and when respondent was unavailable.Â  
Respondent represents, and ODC does not dispute, that his standard procedure was to personally attend real estate closings and, if he could not, to arrange for another attorney to conduct the closing on his behalf.Â  Respondent represents that most of his closings occurred in his presence or that of another lawyer; however, when neither he nor another lawyer were available, it was standard procedure to have McNelis conduct the closing.Â  
Respondent now recognizes that a lawyer must personally conduct the closing of every real estate transaction and that, by knowingly allowing a non-lawyer to close real estate transactions, he assisted in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Respondent represents that it is now his standard procedure to conduct real estate closings in the presence of a lawyer.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, particularly Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation), Rule 5.3(b) (lawyer having direct supervisory authority over non-lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure the personâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations of the lawyer), Rule 5.3(c) (lawyer shall be responsible for conduct of non-lawyer that would be a violation of Rules of Professional Conduct if engaged in by a lawyer), Rule 5.5(b) (lawyer shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the performance of activity that constitutes the unauthorized practice of law), and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct, knowingly assist or induce another to do so, or do so through the acts of another).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Russ and Lee Pye, Justin Enterprises, a South Carolina General Partnership, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Estate of Dorothy T. Fox, John Richard Fox, III, A Personal Representative, Estate of John C. Fox, and G. Thomas Hill (Tommy Hill), Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26193
Heard January 5, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chalmers C. Johnson, of Chalmers Johnson Law Firm, of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Coming B. Gibbs, Jr., of Gibbs & Holmes, of Charleston, for Respondents Estate of Dorothy T. Fox, John Richard Fox, III, as Personal Representative, and Estate of John C. Fox.
        David W. Overstreet and David J. Harmon, both of Carlock Copeland
        Semler & Stair, LLP, of Charleston, for Respondent G. Thomas Hill. 
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE ANDERSON:Â  Russ and Lee Pye, along with their partnership, Justin Enterprises (the Pyes), initiated this action against the Estate of Dorothy T. Fox, the Estate of John C. Fox, John Richard Fox, III (the Foxes), and attorney G. Thomas Hill, alleging (1) abuse of process, (2) civil conspiracy, and (3) a violation of the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceedings Sanctions Act, S.C. Code Ann. section 15-36-10.Â  The circuit court dismissed Hill from the action at the summary judgment stage, and directed a verdict in favor of the Foxes at the close of the Pyesâ€™ case.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Pyes own two adjacent parcels of land, known as Encampment Plantation and Encampment Plantation Drive, located on Highway 17 in Charleston County.Â  The Foxes have an easement for ingress and egress over Encampment Plantation Drive which allows them access from their land to Highway 17.Â  At least one additional parcel separates the Pyesâ€™ land from the Foxesâ€™.Â Â  
Dr. Southard owns property adjacent to the Pyes and has an easement over Encampment Plantation Drive.Â  Soon after Southard purchased his tract he began requesting that the Pyes alter the travel lane over Encampment Plantation Drive.Â  Due to the layout of the lane, Southard was forced to make a ninety-degree turn in order to access his property.Â  Southard engaged in logging on the land, and the cumbersome ninety-degree turn inhibited access for the logging trucks.Â  
Initially, the Pyes resisted Southardâ€™s request to realign the travel lane.Â  According to Mrs. Pyeâ€™s testimony at trial, Southardâ€™s proposal would have required the removal of one of several â€œGrand Treesâ€ which were protected by a county ordinance.Â  However, an Act of God intervened when lightening struck one of the Grand Trees.Â  As a result, the Pyes realigned the lane on Encampment Plantation Drive to turn at a forty-five-degree angle and pass over where the fallen Grand Tree once stood.Â  The Pyes planted shrubbery to cover the former path.Â  Despite the Pyesâ€™ rearrangement of the travel lane, several lawsuits ensued.Â  
On February 27, 2002, attorney Hill filed suit 02-CP-10-903, which was captioned Estate of John Carlton Fox v. Justin Enterprises, A South Carolina General Partnership, Russ Pye and Lee Pye (Suit 903).Â  However, John Carlton Foxâ€™s estate was already closed.Â  Therefore, Suit 903 was eventually dismissed.Â  On May 16, 2002, civil action number 02-CP-10-2131 (Suit 2131) was filed.Â  Suit 2131 alleged the same causes of action as Suit 903, but was captioned Estate of Dorothy T. Fox, John Richard Fox, III, as Personal Representative, John Richard Fox, III, and Developments Unlimited, LLC.Â  The Foxes were dismissed as plaintiffs from Suit 2131 on December 19, 2002, but the action continued with Dr. Southardâ€™s company, Developments Unlimited, LLC, as the sole plaintiff.Â  
Thus, the Foxes filed two lawsuits against the Pyes, but they were eventually dismissed from both suits.Â  Hill represented the Foxes in each action.Â  Based on these lawsuits, the Pyes initiated the case sub judice against the Foxes for abuse of process, civil conspiracy, and violation of S.C. Code Ann. section 15-36-10, the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceedings Sanctions Act, and against Hill on the civil conspiracy and frivolous proceedings act claims.Â  
Hill moved for summary judgment on the civil conspiracy cause of action.Â  The circuit judge granted the motion reasoning the Pyes stated the same claim under the frivolous proceedings act.
Subsequently, Hill filed a motion for summary judgment on the frivolous proceedings act claim.Â  The court scheduled the summary judgment motion in conjunction with the Pyesâ€™ Rule 59 motion to alter or amend.Â  The Pyes agreed to withdraw the frivolous proceedings act claim based on In re Beard, 359 S.C. 351, 597 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The court of appeals, in In re Beard, held that the Frivolous Proceedings Sanctions Act was subject to the general ten-day limitation for post-trial motions.Â  Thus, the Pyesâ€™ claim under the act was time barred.Â  
The court then heard the Pyesâ€™ Rule 59(e) motion.Â  The judge previously had granted summary judgment finding the civil conspiracy claim was adequately addressed by the frivolous proceedings cause of action.Â  According to the Pyes, because the frivolous proceedings claim was not viable, the basis for the courtâ€™s decision did not apply.Â  The following colloquy occurred at the hearing:

  The Court:Â  What are you suggesting that he did outside of his duty as a lawyer?Â  Thatâ€™s the problem.Â  I didnâ€™t hear anything that he did, or didnâ€™t do, that wasnâ€™t really tied to what his responsibilities were to his client.
  Ms. Hunt:Â  Essentially, Your Honor, the evidence sets forth in my memoranda, that Mr. Hill had conversations with Mr. Fox prior to filing the lawsuit that Mr. Foxâ€”Mr. Fox testified in his deposition that he actually took it upon himself to file the lawsuit and that he didnâ€™t inform him that the estate was closed.Â  He acted outside that realm when he takes it upon himself to give people permission to enter upon the plaintiffsâ€™ property to measure treesâ€”he venturedâ€”heâ€™s outside that attorney-client relationship byâ€”
  . . . .
  The Court:Â  [D]o you have any proof that he gave them permission to go anywhere outside the easement?

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ms. Hunt:Â  No, Your Honor.

  The Court:Â  Okay.Â  Then as long as it is confined to the easement, then he had a duty to do what he did.Â  Okay. Thank you.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ms. Hunt:Â  Thank you, Your Honor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Court:Â  I deny the Motion to Reconsider.Â  
The case was tried before a jury with two causes of action surviving against the Foxesâ€”abuse of process and civil conspiracy.Â  At the close of the Pyesâ€™ case, the Foxes moved for a directed verdict.Â  The court found no evidence of an ulterior purpose or willful abuse of process in the proceedings the Foxes initiated.Â  Therefore, the judge directed a verdict on the abuse of process claim.Â  The Pyes do not appeal this ruling.Â  Next, the circuit court addressed the civil conspiracy claim:

  As to the conspiracy, I understand the dilemma here, Ms. Hunt, and I understand youâ€™re contemplating appealing that.Â  I realize that situation.Â  There is no evidence, because Mr. Hill had been dismissed prior to this lawsuit.Â  So there was noâ€”you couldnâ€™t have really had any testimony concerning that.Â  So, thereâ€™s no evidence concerning a conspiracy on the part of Mr. Fox.Â  He canâ€™t conspire with himself.Â  That being the case, the Court would also grant the directed verdict as to the conspiracy action and, therefore, directs a verdict for the Defendant in this matter.

The Pyes present two issues on appeal: (1) whether the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to dismiss the civil conspiracy cause of action against Hill; and (2) whether the circuit court erred in directing a verdict in favor of the Foxes.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary Judgment
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 611 S.E.2d 922 (2005); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.Â  Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 608 S.E.2d 587 (Ct. App. 2005).
Directed Verdict
In ruling on motions for directed verdict or judgment notwithstanding the verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.Â  The trial court must deny the motions when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should have been denied.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003); Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995).Â  In deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict motion, the trial court is concerned only with the existence or nonexistence of evidence.Â  Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 15, 567 S.E.2d 881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
This Court will reverse only where there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling, or where the ruling was controlled by an error of law.Â  Clark v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 382-83, 608 S.E.2d 573, 576 (2005); Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999); Abu-Shawareb v. S.C. State Univ., 364 S.C. 358, 613 S.E.2d 757 (Ct. App. 2005); Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 300, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Essentially, this Court must resolve whether it would be reasonably conceivable to have a verdict for a party opposing the motion under the facts as liberally construed in the opposing partyâ€™s favor.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002); Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Summary Judgment
A.Â  Issue Preservation
The Pyes contend the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Hill.Â  
Generally, â€œan attorney is immune from liability to third persons arising from the performance of his professional activities as an attorney on behalf of and with the knowledge of his client.â€Â  Gaar v. North Myrtle Beach Realty Co., Inc., 287 S.C. 525, 528, 339 S.E.2d 887, 889 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  In Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995), this Court held â€œan attorney may be held liable for conspiracy where, in addition to representing his client, he breaches some independent duty to a third person or acts in his own personal interest, outside the scope of his representation of the client.â€Â  
For the first time on appeal, the Pyes allege that Hill breached an independent duty owed to them.Â  According to the Pyes, Hill owed the Pyes a duty based on Rule 11, SCRCP and S.C. Code Ann. section 16-17-10, the barratry statute. This issue was not presented to or ruled upon by the trial judge and is not preserved for our review.Â  
It is well settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved.Â  See generally Holy Loch Distribs., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 531 S.E.2d 282 (2000); Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 529 S.E.2d 543 (2000).
The Pyes raise for the first time on appeal the theory that Hill should be held liable for civil conspiracy on the basis of a duty he owed to them.Â  They did not present this issue at the initial summary judgment hearing or at the Rule 59(e) hearing.Â  Therefore, this issue is not properly before us, and we will not consider it now for the first time on appeal.Â Â Â  
The theory the Pyes did raise to the trial judge at the Rule 59(e) hearing was that Hill should be held liable for acting outside the scope of his professional duties and in his own interest.Â  In support of this argument the Pyes presented two factual incidents: (1) Hill allegedly asked Fox to join in litigation against the Pyes and then filed a lawsuit in the name of the Estate of John Carlton Fox without Richard Foxâ€™s permission; and (2) Hill granted a third party permission to enter Encampment Plantation Drive to take some measurements.Â  The circuit court specifically addressed the granting permission to enter the land and declared that act was not outside the scope of Hillâ€™s representation of his client.Â  The Pyes do not appeal this aspect of the judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  
The court did not address Hillâ€™s alleged solicitation of Fox or his filing of the lawsuit without the clientâ€™s knowledge.Â  Hill contends that because the circuit court did not rule on this issue at the Rule 59(e) hearing, it is not preserved.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally, an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the circuit court to be preserved.Â  Elam v. S. Carolina Depâ€™t of Trans., 361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004) (noting a party must file a Rule 59(e) motion â€œwhen an issue or argument has been raised, but not ruled on, in order to preserve it for appellate reviewâ€).Â  However, an exception to this rule exists where an issue is raised but not ruled upon at a Rule 59(e) hearing.Â  In Coward Hund, the court of appeals explained:

  â€œThe purpose of Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment[,] is to request the trial judge to â€˜reconsider matters properly encompassed in a decision on the merits.â€™â€Â  Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992) (quoting Budinich v. Becton Dickinson and Co., 486 U.S. 196, 200, 108 S.Ct. 1717, 100 L.Ed.2d 178 (1988)).Â  As one authority has noted, â€œOnce the issue has been properly raised by a Rule 59(e) motion, it appears that it is preserved and a second motion is not required if the trial court does not specifically rule on the issue so raised.â€Â  James F. Flanagan South Carolina Civil Procedure 475 (2d ed. 1996).

Coward Hund Const. Co., Inc. v. Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 1, 4, 518 S.E.2d 56, 58 (Ct. App. 1999 (emphasis added); see also Collins Music Co., Inc. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 579 S.E.2d 524 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Coward Hund).Â  In Pressley v. Lancaster County, 343 S.C. 696, 542 S.E.2d 366 (Ct. App. 2001), the court of appeals, citing Coward Hund, applied this principle when the court addressed the merits of an argument which Pressley raised at trial and in a Rule 59(e) motion, but which the trial court â€œsummarily denied.â€Â  See Pressley, 343 S.C. at 706 n.4, 542 S.E.2d at 371 n.4.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Professor Flanagan further edifies:

  One commentator noted:Â  â€œLawyers cannot force a trial judge to address a disputed issue.â€Â  Moreover, the Supreme Court identifies two ways to preserve the issue:Â  â€œa ruling by the trial judge or a post-trial motion.â€Â  The language implies that a properly requested ruling under Rule 59 is sufficient without a specific judicial decision on the matter.Â  

South Carolina Civil Procedure 475-76 (2nd ed. 1996) (footnotes omitted) (quoting Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. Preserving Error for Appeal, South Carolina Lawyer, 15, 18 (Mar./Apr. 1995) and Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 427 S.E.2d 673 (1993)).
In the instant case, the Pyes raised the issue whether Hill acted outside the scope of his professional responsibilities by allegedly soliciting Fox to join in litigation against the Pyes and by filing the suit without Foxâ€™s knowledge.Â  The Pyes asserted this theory both at the summary judgment hearing and the Rule 59(e) hearing.Â  Consequently, this issue is preserved for our review, even though the circuit judge did not rule on the theory.Â  
B.Â  Civil Conspiracy
The elements of a civil conspiracy in South Carolina are (1) the combination of two or more people, (2) for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff, (3) which causes special damages.Â  LaMotte v. Punch Line of Columbia, Inc., 296 S.C. 66, 370 S.E.2d 711 (1988); Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 49, 619 S.E.2d 437, 453 (Ct. App. 2005); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Peoples Federal Savings & Loan Assâ€™n of S. Carolina v. Resources Planning Corp., 358 S.C. 460, 470, 596 S.E.2d 51, 56-57 (2004) (â€œA civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more parties joined for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff and thereby causing special damage.â€) (citation omitted).Â  It is essential that the plaintiff prove all of these elements in order to recover.Â  Lyon v. Sinclair Refining Co., 189 S.C. 136, 200 S.E. 78 (1938).Â  The â€œessential considerationâ€ in civil conspiracy â€œis not whether lawful or unlawful acts or means are employed to further the conspiracy, but whether the primary purpose or object of the combination is to injure the plaintiff.â€Â  Lee v. Chesterfield General Hosp., Inc., 289 S.C. 6, 13, 344 S.E.2d 379, 383 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
â€œ[I]n order to establish a conspiracy, evidence, direct or circumstantial, must be produced from which a party may reasonably infer the joint assent of the minds of two or more parties to the prosecution of the unlawful enterprise.â€Â  Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 601, 358 S.E.2d 150, 153 (Ct. App. 1987); accord Cowburn, 366 S.C. at 49, 619 S.E.2d at 453.Â  This Court has observed:

  Conspiracy may be inferred from the very nature of the acts done, the relationship of the parties, the interests of the alleged conspirators, and other circumstances.Â  Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 358 S.E.2d 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  â€œCivil conspiracy is an act which is by its very nature covert and clandestine and usually not susceptible of proof by direct evidence. . . .â€ Id. at 601, 358 S.E.2d at 153.Â  An action for civil conspiracy is an action at law; the trial judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  Gynecology Clinic v. Cloer, 334 S.C. 555, 514 S.E.2d 592 (1999).

Peoples Federal, 358 S.C. at 470, 596 S.E.2d at 57.

The gravamen of the tort of civil conspiracy is the damage resulting to the plaintiff from an overt act done pursuant to the combination, not the agreement or combination per se.Â  Lee, 289 S.C. 6, 344 S.E.2d 379.Â  â€œ[A]n unlawful act is not a necessary element of the tort.â€Â  Id. at 11, 344 S.E.2d at 382.Â  Because the quiddity of a civil conspiracy claim is the damage resulting to the plaintiff, the damages alleged must go beyond the damages alleged in other causes of action.Â  Vaught v. Waites, 300 S.C. 201, 387 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1989).
Although the theory of Hillâ€™s scope of representation is properly preserved, we do not need to reach this issue.Â  Instead, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment under Rule 220(c), SCACR and Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000).Â  The Pyes failed to establish the elements of civil conspiracy.Â  There was absolutely no evidence submitted at the summary judgment stage supporting an agreement between Hill and Richard Fox to injure the Pyes.Â  The only evidence the Pyes proffered to establish that Hillâ€™s actions were outside the scope of his representation is the following statement from Richard Foxâ€™s deposition testimony:Â  â€œI stopped by Mr. Hillâ€™s office and he asked me if we wanted to get involved in opening the road and I said yes.Â  And at the timeâ€”I should have probably given him more information but he took it on his own and thatâ€™s when he filed it under my fatherâ€™s estate which had already been closed.â€Â  Yet, even in a light most favorable to the Pyes, Richard Foxâ€™s statement does not establish any wrongful intent by the Foxes to injure the Pyes.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s summary judgment on the basis that the Pyes failed to offer proof of an agreement between Hill and the Foxes to injure the Pyes.Â  
II.Â  Directed Verdict
At the conclusion of the Pyesâ€™ case, the circuit court directed a verdict for the Foxes on civil conspiracy, finding that since Hill had been dismissed from the case, there could be no testimony about a conspiracy.Â  The Pyes maintain that Hillâ€™s immunity from liability does not eviscerate their case against the Foxes for conspiracy.Â  They claim the court should have considered the evidence of conspiracy against the Foxes rather than directing a verdict.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR and Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000).
After reviewing the evidence presented at trial, we conclude the Pyes failed to satisfy the elements of civil conspiracy.Â  The Pyes did not proffer any evidence of an agreement by Hill and the Foxes to injure the Pyes.Â  A directed verdict is proper where the evidence raises no issues for the jury as to liability.Â  See Carolina Home Builders, Inc. v. Armstrong Furnace Co., 259 S.C. 346, 358, 191 S.E.2d 774, 779 (1972).Â  Therefore, we affirm the courtâ€™s directed verdict in favor of the Foxes based on the Pyesâ€™ failure to present evidence of a necessary element of civil conspiracy.Â  
CONCLUSION
Hillâ€™s liability based on a duty owed to the Pyes was never raised to the circuit court and is not preserved for our review.Â  Although the court did not rule on the issue of whether Hill ambulated outside the scope of his professional duties, the argument was raised at the summary judgment hearing and at the Rule 59(e) hearing.Â  Consequently, the issue is adequately preserved.Â  However, because the Pyes failed to offer evidence on all of the elements of civil conspiracy, we affirm summary judgment.Â  Similarly, we affirm the directed verdict in favor of the Foxes for failure to submit any evidence establishing a necessary element of civil conspiracy.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

text:
Edwards v Campbell

<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Lisa Rea Edwards, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert Keith Campbell, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26194
Heard June 21, 2006 - Filed July 24, 2006 

REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jim S. Brooks, of Jim Brooks & Associates, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
        J. Edwin McDonnell, of McDonnell & Noll, LLC, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a direct appeal from the family courtâ€™s order granting appellant $7,410.28 in past due child support, but denying appellantâ€™s other claims, including a request for compound interest on the child support award.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s order in material part.Â  However, because appellant is entitled to post judgment interest, we remand this matter to the family court for a calculation of simple post judgment interest on the $7,410.28 award of past due child support.
FACTS
Appellant Lisa Rea Edwards (Mother) and respondent Robert Keith Campbell, Jr. (Father) married in August 1981 and had two sons, one in July 1982 and the other in January 1985.Â  The parties separated, however, and finalized their divorce in 1990.Â  Pursuant to their separation agreement, Father agreed to pay $576.52 per month in child support beginning November 1, 1990.Â  In addition, the parties agreed that Father would keep health insurance coverage for the two children and pay the childrenâ€™s medical bills.
 In 1993, Mother brought a contempt action against Father.Â  After a hearing, the family court ordered Father to pay, inter alia:Â  (1) $205.34 for past due medical bills of the children; (2) $1,867.32 for an outstanding MasterCard debt; and (3) $5,077.00 still owed for property division.Â  
The instant case relates to Motherâ€™s November 2003 filing of a Rule to Show Cause wherein she claimed Father owed her the following:Â  (1) $38,230.81 in past due child support and alimony;[1] (2) $49,714.15 in unpaid medical bills; (3) $7,830.92 stemming from Fatherâ€™s failure to pay the medical bills and property division items in the 1993 Order; and (4) $24,535.16 in â€œother child obligationsâ€ including expenses for the elder sonâ€™s three-year attendance at Camden Military Academy.Â  
The family court held a hearing on the Rule to Show Cause in September 2004.Â  Relying on an article published in the South Carolina Lawyer,[2] Mother specifically requested that the family court award compound interest for the past due child support and medical bills.
Through her own testimony and exhibits, Mother claimed that Father was $17,390.16 in arrears on child support; with compound interest, she calculated that Father owed a total of $34,831.23 in past due child support.Â  Regarding past due medical expenses, Mother stated that Father owed $5,678.28.Â  With compound interest, Mother calculated that Father owed a total of $11,002.86 for the medical expenses.Â  Mother also testified that Father owed her on the property division and medical bills portions of the 1993 Order, with the addition of post judgment interest.Â  Finally, Mother stated that Father owed her for half of various other expenses for the children, including non-tuition costs associated with the elder sonâ€™s attendance at Camden Military. Â 
On cross-examination, Mother testified to the following, inter alia:Â  (1) her older son turned 18 in 2000; (2) her younger son turned 18 in January 2003; and (3) she collected child support through May 2003.Â  In addition, at the time of the hearing, Mother owed a substantial amount of money in unpaid taxes.[3]Â  Finally, Mother acknowledged that in the 1993 action, no mention was made regarding any past due child support from 1990 onward; yet in the instant action, she was claiming past due child support from April 1990 through May 2003.
Father testified at the hearing that:Â  (1) he overpaid Mother by at least $20,000 or $24,000; (2) he carried insurance on his sons until they were 18; (3) he usually took the children to the doctor; and (4) he was not given medical bills that he did not pay.Â  Father also testified that although he did not have a record of it, he paid by check within 30 days of the 1993 Order what the court had determined he should pay.Â  
At the conclusion of the hearing, the family court judge indicated she had â€œcredibility issues with bothâ€ parties.Â  In the written order, the family court made the following pertinent findings regarding Motherâ€™s past due child support claim:Â  (1) Father did not overpay Mother, but â€œhe owes her substantially less than she claims;â€ (2) the amount owed by Father would begin with February 1993 because no child support delinquency was found in the 1993 Order; (3) Mother was entitled to $67,452.84 in child support; (4) according to Motherâ€™s own exhibit, Father paid Mother $55,100.00; (5) because Father never sought a reduction in child support when the older child turned 18 in July 2000, Father would be given a $4,942.56 credit; and (6) therefore, Father owed Mother $7,410.28 in past due child support.Â  
The family court specifically denied Motherâ€™s claim for compound interest.Â  In addition, the family court denied Motherâ€™s request for medical expenses.Â  Finally, the family court found Motherâ€™s testimony was not credible regarding her claim that Father did not pay the medical bills and property division items from the 1993 Order.Â  
The family court ordered that the $7,410.28 owed by Father for past due child support should be paid through the Spartanburg County Clerk of Court â€œat the rate of $200.00 per month, plus a five percent collection cost for a total of $210.00 per month.â€Â  Beyond the denial of Motherâ€™s request for compound interest, there was no specific mention of post-judgment interest in the family courtâ€™s order.
ISSUE

  Did the family court err by denying compound interest on the past due child support, or in the alternative, was it error to fail to award simple post judgment interest?

DISCUSSION
Mother argues that the family court erred in failing to award â€œsome formâ€ of post judgment interest from the date each child support payment became due.Â  Moreover, Mother claims she is entitled to compound interest, or, if that request is denied by this Court, simple interest at the statutory rate.Â  While the family court correctly denied Motherâ€™s claim for compound interest, we agree Mother is entitled to simple post judgment interest.
It is well-settled that â€œfixed awards of money for equitable distribution shall accrue interest at the post-judgment rate from the date of the judgment, or in the case of specified periodic payments from the date each payment becomes due and owing.â€Â  Casey v. Casey, 311 S.C. 243, 245-46, 428 S.E.2d 714, 716 (1993) (emphasis added).Â  In Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 492 S.E.2d 86 (1997), this Court made clear that while Casey involved an equitable division award, the same principle applies to past due alimony and child support.Â  We explained as follows:

  Here, Husband was ordered in the 1982 divorce decree to make monthly payments of alimony and child support to Wife.Â  That decree constituted the â€œjudgmentâ€ ordering the periodic payments. Â The fact that Wife had to get a contempt order in 1994 because of Husband's failure to meet his alimony and child support obligations does not mean the 1994 order was the first judgment ordering such payments.Â  To alter the interest requirement in the way Husband suggests would reward Husband for failing to meet his obligations when they were due.

Id. at 114, 492 S.E.2d at 96.Â  Thus, the Casey principle applies to periodic payments such as child support, and the interest is calculated on each installment from the time each payment became due.[4]Â  Id.; see also Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 102, 529 S.E.2d 14, 17 (2000) (â€œWhere the law allows interest as a matter of course, it is unnecessary to make demand for it in the pleadingsâ€). 
In this case, the family court denied Motherâ€™s request for compound interest.Â  Mother argues that the pertinent subsection of the post judgment interest statute is â€œpenal in natureâ€ and therefore should be interpreted as providing for compound interest.Â  In addition, Mother argues that based on the statutory language in effect at the time these child support judgments came due, the interest should be compounded annually. Â We disagree.
Section 34-31-20(B) of the S.C. Code provides for post judgment interest.Â  Prior to 2001, the legal post judgment interest rate was â€œfourteen percent per annum;â€ the statute was amended in 2000, and as of January 1, 2001, the rate became â€œtwelve percent a year.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (1987 & Supp. 2000) (emphasis added).Â  
Mother contends that because of two late nineteenth-century cases, the above-emphasized language in the statute means that the interest should be compound, rather than simple.Â  See Bowen v Barksdale, 33 S.C. 142, 11 S.E. 640 (1890); Carolina Sav. Bank v Parrott, 30 S.C. 61, 8 S.E. 199 (1888).Â  The Parrott and Bowen cases, however, are inapposite to the issue of whether the language of the post judgment interest statute authorizes compound interest.[5]Â  Instead, we believe that if the Legislature intended for interest to be compounded in a certain way pursuant to Section 34-31-20(B), â€œit could have plainly said so.â€ Â Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 277, 625 S.E.2d 636, 640 (2006) (finding that charging a flat rate of interest on redeemed properties was intended where the statute did not specify that the interest be compounded).
Indeed, we note that the Legislature amended Section 34-31-20(B) just last year, and this section now provides as follows, in pertinent part:

  A money decree or judgment of a court enrolled or entered must draw interest according to law. Â The legal rate of interest is equal to the prime rate as listed in the first edition of the Wall Street Journal published for each calendar year for which the damages are awarded, plus four percentage points, compounded annually.â€¦Â  This section applies to all judgments entered on or after July 1, 2005.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§34-31-20(B) (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).
Given that the Legislature has only recently expressed a clear intent that post judgment interest be â€œcompounded annually,â€ the family court properly denied Motherâ€™s request for compound interest.Â  See Buist, supra (if Legislature had intended certain result in statute, it would have said so); see also Hainer v. American Med. Intâ€™l, Inc., 328 S.C. 128, 134, 492 S.E.2d 103, 106 (â€œThis Court cannot construe a statute without regard to its plain and ordinary meaning, and may not resort to subtle or forced construction in an attempt to limit or expand a statuteâ€™s scope.â€).
In sum, the family court did not err in denying Motherâ€™s request for compound interest.Â  However, because the post judgment interest statute applies to family court judgments relating to periodic payments such as child support, Mother is entitled to post judgment interest from the date each child support payment came due.Â  See Thornton, supra; see also Casey, supra (where no contrary provision is made by the family court, a domestic money judgment bears post judgment interest at the statutory rate).
Accordingly, we remand this matter to the family court to calculate simple post judgment interest on the $7,410.28 child support award.
CONCLUSION
We hold Mother is entitled to simple post judgment interest on the $7,410.28 award of past due child support. Â Therefore, we remand this matter to the family court for a calculation of post judgment interest from the time each payment became due.Â  See Thornton; supra; Casey, supra.
REMANDED.[6]
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The partiesâ€™ separation agreement provided alimony for Mother in the amount of $200 per month.Â  Mother remarried in May 1992.
[2] See Gregory S. Forman, Contingency Fees and Interest in Collecting Back Child Support and Alimony, 14-May S.C. Law. 27 (May 2003) (hereinafter â€œthe Forman articleâ€).Â  Mother submitted the article to the family court as an exhibit.
[3] Mother testified that she had a manufactured home sales company but it was no longer in business.Â  Her financial declaration listed that she owed over $214,000 to the IRS and over $116,000 to the S.C. Dept. of Revenue.Â  Fatherâ€™s counsel questioned Mother about $700,000 in recorded federal tax liens. Â 
[4] We note, however, Caseyâ€™s emphasis on the fact that the family court retains considerable discretion regarding the award of interest:

  We leave intact the family courtâ€™s broad discretion to provide for the payment of interest as part of the equitable distribution award.Â  Thus, the family court may provide for the amortization of payments with a rate of interest different from the post-judgment rate or deny interest altogether on payments due at a future date.â€¦Â  Where, however, no contrary provision is made by the decreeing court, a domestic money judgment bears post-judgment interest at the statutory rate.

Casey, 311 S.C. at 246, 428 S.E.2d at 716.
[5] The Parrott case indicates that charging â€œinterest upon interestâ€ at a rate above the usury law might be permissible in a written agreement between two private parties without violating the usury law, but it would not be appropriate for a bank to charge above the statutory usury rate.Â  Stated another way, a bank is allowed to compound interest annually on a loan, as long as this is specifically stated in the contract and the rate does not exceed the usury law.Â  See Tate v. Lenhardt, 110 S.C. 569, 96 S.E. 720, 722 (1918) (after Parrott, it became the common practice for banks and money lenders to expressly agree to compound interest). Â Similarly, the Bowen case involved an issue regarding the rate of interest a promissory note should bear after maturity of the obligation.Â  Bowen stands for the proposition that private parties may expressly agree to a rate of interest that is higher than the statutory rate, and also may contract to have the interest compounded.
[6] Appellantâ€™s remaining issues are affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Issues 3 and 4: Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005) (this Court is not required to ignore the fact that the family court judge, who actually saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate credibility and assign comparative weight to the witnessesâ€™ testimony); Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981) (this Courtâ€™s broad scope of review in family court cases does not require the Court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and it does not relieve the appellant of the burden of convincing this Court that the family court committed error).

title: Amendments to Rule 404, SCACR
description: This order amends Rule 404, SCACR, to specify that an attorney who files more than six pro hac vice applications in a calendar year is considered regularly engaged in the practice of law in South Carolna.
text:
The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In re: Amendments to Rule 404, SCACR

ORDER

Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution,   Rule 404, SCACR, is hereby amended as follows: 
 
Rule (b) shall state:

  (b) Prohibitions on Admissions Pro Hac Vice. An   attorney may not appear pro hac vice if the attorney is a resident of South   Carolina, is regularly employed in South Carolina, or is regularly engaged in   the practice of law or in substantial business or professional activities in   South Carolina, unless the attorney has filed an application for admission under   Rule 402, SCACR. Notwithstanding any other provision herein, an attorney who   files more than six applications for admission pro hac vice in a calendar year,   including applications for purposes of Rule 404(h), is considered regularly   engaged in the practice of law in South Carolina.
	 

Rule (h) shall state:  

  (h) Limitations on Provision of Legal Services Pursuant   to Rule 5.5(c)(3). A lawyer who is not admitted to practice in South   Carolina who seeks to provide legal services pursuant to Rule 5.5(c)(3) in more   than three matters in a calendar year shall be presumed to be providing legal   services on a regular, not temporary, basis. 
	 

These amendments shall take effect immediately.  
IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                             J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
      s/E.C. Burnett, III                                 J.
      s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
July 20, 2006
